Instead, they may have been sporadically used as ritual gathering places, similar to Maya pyramids or Stonehenge. Dr. Loader's analysis of soil samples suggests the geoglyphs were built in taller vegetation, not visible above the forest canopy, raising questions about their purpose. The research also indicates that the Amazonian forests were not pristine before European arrival, but had been artificially influenced by humans over 6,000 years, with economically valuable trees like palms being cultivated. This practice, likened to a "prehistoric supermarket," may have left a legacy in the biodiversity of Acre's remaining forests.

Nick Kyrgios, a 21-year-old Australian tennis player ranked 12th globally, defeated world number 29 Sam Querrey 6-4, 6-4 in 53 minutes to advance to the second round of the Shanghai Masters. Kyrgios, who recently won the Japan Open, expressed feeling tired and bored during the match, which led to his less vocal demeanor. He attributed his fatigue to the travel and late arrivals due to the tournament's location, an hour from Shanghai city center. Kyrgios also mentioned poor sleep and a challenging commute to the courts. This victory comes after Kyrgios was fined $1,500 last year at the Shanghai Masters for a profanity-laced outburst, where he described the event as a "circus".

Scientists and charities are advocating for the expansion of the HPV vaccination program in Wales to include boys, aiming to prevent head and neck cancers. Currently, the vaccine is administered to girls aged 12 and 13 to protect against cervical cancer. The number of head and neck cancer cases is rising, with the average age of affected individuals being 55 and three-quarters of them being men. Dr. Mererid Evans, a consultant oncologist, noted a shift in demographics over the past decade, with younger, non-smoking individuals, often with families, being diagnosed. Jon Antoniazzi from Tenovus Cancer Care emphasized that HPV causes 5% of global cancers and urged the Welsh government to take a proactive approach to public health. The Welsh government is currently awaiting advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making any changes to the program. An HPV vaccination program for girls was introduced in 2008, with 85% of girls in Wales having been vaccinated.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old student from West Calder High School, passed away after battling a rare form of blood cancer, gamma delta T-cell lymphoma. His mother, Allison, announced his death on his Facebook page, expressing her devastation. Jak had been documenting his journey on a Facebook page called "Jak's Journey," which garnered over 28,000 followers. His positive attitude and love for Rangers FC touched many in West Lothian and beyond. Despite his illness, Jak attended his school prom for a brief 10 minutes, where he was greeted by former Rangers captain Barry Ferguson. His family collected his Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy for overcoming adversity at the event. Jak's story included visits from various sports stars and the cast of Wicked, as well as personal moments like playing his tuba and spending time with his girlfriend. In January, doctors informed Jak and his family that his cancer had spread, leading to the decision not to pursue further treatment. Jak continued to inspire with his resilience, urging support for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research. His family organized various events, including a football match, to raise funds for charity in his memory.

In a low-scoring match, Egypt defeated Uganda 1-0 in Port-Gentil, advancing Egypt to face Ghana in their final group game. The only goal came in the 89th minute when Mohamed Salah assisted Abdallah El Said, who scored past Uganda's goalkeeper Denis Onyango. Uganda's Joseph Ochaya had a goal disallowed for offside earlier in the game. The win secures Egypt's spot in the next round, while Uganda, participating in their first tournament since 1978, is eliminated. Ghana had already qualified with a 1-0 victory over Mali earlier in the day. The match was played on a deteriorating pitch, with both teams struggling to create scoring opportunities. Egypt's veteran goalkeeper Essam El Hadary and Uganda's Denis Onyango made several crucial saves. Uganda now faces Mali in their final group game, needing a win and a significant result in the Ghana-Egypt match to advance.

Lancashire County Council has selected land on the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College's Westbank campus for a new railway station. This decision comes after a comparative study by Network Rail, which also considered a site near the Concourse shopping centre. The sports college closed in August, and the Westbank campus, owned by Newcastle College, is currently unused. The new station, proposed in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, would provide two direct trains to Liverpool per hour. County councillor John Fillis highlighted the site's potential for future expansion, its good highway access, and connectivity to the town and surrounding areas. Skelmersdale, designated a new town in 1961, is one of the largest towns in the north west of England without its own railway station. The council will now begin the process of acquiring the necessary land.

A man in his late 40s was arrested after police discovered a sophisticated cannabis cultivation setup, referred to as a "grow house", during a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning.

A 28-year-old woman of Kurdish origin was severely injured in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, after being dragged by her neck through several streets by her ex-partner. The attack occurred late Sunday, leading to an emergency operation and her subsequent transfer to a specialist clinic. The suspect, a 38-year-old man also of Kurdish origin from Bad Muender, turned himself in to authorities. Both the victim and the suspect are German citizens. The motive for the attack remains unclear. Police have secured the crime scene and are seeking witnesses.

The study conducted by Cass Business School, the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin, analyzed data from 4,600 full-time workers in Australia, aiming to address the "reticent female" theory regarding women's reluctance to ask for pay rises. The research found no evidence supporting this theory, as women were just as likely as men to request a pay increase. However, when comparing like-for-like male and female workers, men were 25% more likely to receive a pay rise when they asked. The study also debunked the notion that women avoid asking for raises due to fear of upsetting their boss or deviating from a female stereotype. The researchers considered factors such as employer size, industry, parental status, and qualifications. The findings suggest a potential element of discrimination against women, as Professor Andrew Oswald from the University of Warwick noted. Interestingly, the study revealed that women and men under 40 asked for and received pay rises at equal rates, indicating a possible shift in negotiating behavior among younger generations. Dr. Amanda Goodall from Cass Business School suggested that this trend could continue as younger women gain more seniority.

Oxford City Council is facing a challenge in finding a new burial site due to the lack of suitable land within the city. The council has been conducting ground investigations on potential sites, but none have been deemed suitable due to factors such as size, ground conditions, high water tables, or restrictive covenants. Two existing cemeteries in Wolvercote and Botley still have available space, but they are projected to be full by 2018 and 2021 respectively. After these are filled, the council will only be able to accommodate the reopening of family plots, reserved plots, and the interment of ashes. The last expansion of burial space in Oxford occurred in 1932. Despite these challenges, the council remains committed to exploring options and has not given up on finding a new site.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt), taking place in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis from July 19-22, is introducing an augmented reality app. This app will enable visitors to access online content, such as videos, band interviews, and sign information, by scanning items like signs and posters on the festival site using their phones or tablets. Notable acts performing this year include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. Festival director Caroline Maclennan highlighted that this feature aims to enhance the visitor experience and allow global interaction with the festival, providing real-time updates, ticket purchasing options, and a taste of the festival's atmosphere remotely.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died shortly after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. He narrowly beat Thistlecrack in a closely contested race. The British Horseracing Authority (BHA) confirmed that Many Clouds suffered from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, a rare condition that can occur in horses with no underlying health issues across all disciplines of sport horses. Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, overheating, and wobbling on his feet, but he had never collapsed before. He was owned by Trevor Hemmings and trained by Oliver Sherwood, who described him as the "horse of a lifetime". Despite his past health issues, the BHA's acting chief veterinary officer, Tony Welsh, stated that the haemorrhage was not linked to any significant underlying health issues. The BHA is committed to further understanding the causes of such incidents and exploring ways to prevent them.

Davina, formerly known as David Ayrton, is a 34-year-old individual charged with raping a 15-year-old girl in a Portsmouth garage in 2004. Davina, who has learning difficulties, has denied the charge. The victim, who had only consumed a can and a half of beer, recalled the incident clearly and stated she had shouted and sworn at Davina to stop, but her friends did not wake up. Davina attempted suicide last summer. She changed her name in 2012 and disclosed the assault to a care home worker in 2014. Judge Ian Pearson remanded Davina into custody, citing concerns about her potential risk to herself and others if released on bail. She will be held in a male prison in Winchester, with special protocols in place for her detention. Davina will be sentenced on 3 March, and the case has been described as unusual and challenging.

In Rio, the Serbian duo lost 6-4, 6-4 to Brazilian pair Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in the Olympic tournament. This defeat followed Novak Djokovic's unexpected elimination in the singles event the previous day, where he was defeated by Argentina's Juan Martin del Potro. Djokovic, the world's top-ranked player and a 12-time Grand Slam winner, also experienced a shock third-round exit at Wimbledon in July, losing to American Sam Querrey. Despite these setbacks, Djokovic rebounded by securing his 30th Masters title in Toronto prior to the Olympics.

The passage describes an upcoming chainsaw carving competition scheduled for Saturday in Carrbridge, located in the Cairngorms. The event attracts carvers from various countries including Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US. Participants are restricted to using only chainsaws for their creations, which typically depict animals and human figures. Pete Bowsher, the reigning champion from Moffat, will participate to defend his title and keep the Claymore Trophy.

Dan Biggar, a 27-year-old Welsh rugby player, is nearing a return to action after a severe foot injury sustained in September during a World Cup warm-up match against Italy. He is currently in a pre-season training phase and aims to regain fitness before the Six Nations tournament in February. Webb, who has been capped 16 times for Wales, has extended his contract with both the Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, opting to stay with his home region despite offers from other clubs. He hopes to be ready for Wales' Six Nations opener against Ireland in Dublin on February 7.

On Tuesday morning, US border agents intercepted two men attempting to smuggle MDMA from Canada to San Francisco, five miles east of Sumas, Washington. One of the men, Jeffrey Laviolette, was apprehended immediately, while the other, Nathan Hall, fled and was later arrested in British Columbia. The backpacks they were carrying contained 58lb (26kg) of ecstasy. A third individual, Kali Henifin, and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, were arrested for planning to transport the drugs. Henifin allegedly monitored police radio communication upon hearing a report of a shooting. The three men in US custody face charges of conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution. The area is known for drug and firearm smuggling, and such prosecutions are common for the US attorney's office in the Western District of Washington.

The NSPCC's Childline service reported a significant increase in counseling sessions for children dealing with online abuse, from approximately 2,400 in 2011-12 to over 4,500 in the past year. The actual number of children suffering from online abuse is believed to be much higher. Children as young as seven have reported being tormented, abused, and scared to attend school due to cyberbullying. Childline's president, Dame Esther Rantzen, emphasized the severity of the issue, stating that cyberbullying can follow children home, causing continuous misery and humiliation. She urged adults, parents, and teachers to intervene and protect children, as bullying does not resolve on its own and often escalates. The report's release coincides with Anti-Bullying Week, an initiative by the Anti Bullying Alliance aimed at combating the problem through collaboration with parents, schools, and other organizations. A young person who contacted Childline shared their experience of being told to kill themselves by online peers, highlighting the emotional distress caused by cyberbullying. The advice given by Childline for dealing with bullying includes seeking help and support.

The passage discusses a series of diplomatic actions following a UN Security Council resolution condemning Israeli settlement construction in the West Bank and East Jerusalem. The resolution, which the US chose not to veto, was met with fury from Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who accused the White House of drafting and pushing for the resolution's passage. The US denied these allegations, hoping the resolution would prompt Israel to reconsider its policies. Over 500,000 Jews reside in approximately 140 settlements, considered illegal under international law, though Israel disputes this. The resolution emphasized that settlements have no legal validity and pose a significant obstacle to a two-state solution. In response, Netanyahu recalled Israel's ambassadors to New Zealand and Senegal, cut aid to Senegal, and cancelled a visit by Ukraine's prime minister. He also summoned the ambassadors of the US and the 14 Security Council nations that voted in favor of the resolution. Initially, plans were in place to authorize 492 new homes in Ramat Shlomo and Ramot settlements, but this vote was postponed at Netanyahu's request to avoid further straining relations with the US ahead of Secretary of State John Kerry's speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Kerry's speech was expected to outline his vision for resolving the conflict and address criticisms from the Israeli government. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas viewed the resolution as a positive step towards the upcoming Middle East peace conference in France on January 15.

Prince William paid tribute to Queen Elizabeth II on the eve of her 90th birthday, praising her as a "guiding example" of a good monarch. The Queen, accompanied by Prince Philip, visited Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office to mark the 500th anniversary of the postal service. She was welcomed with a performance by the Royal Mail choir. The royals later opened a new bandstand in Alexandra Gardens, where children sang "Happy Birthday". Prime Minister David Cameron and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn expressed their admiration for the Queen's service. Prince William, in a BBC interview, acknowledged criticism about his commitment to royal duties but emphasized his serious approach to his responsibilities. He stated that he finds his own way to balance duty and personal life, learning from his grandmother's example. Ten stamps were released to celebrate the Queen's birthday, featuring four generations of the Royal Family. On her actual birthday, the Queen and Prince Philip will walk around Windsor and light a beacon, initiating a series of over 900 beacons worldwide. US President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama will join the Queen for lunch at Windsor Castle the following day. The republican pressure group, Republic, criticized the extensive media coverage of the Queen's birthday, stating that it was disproportionate and failed to provide fair and balanced reporting.

In a League Two versus Premier League EFL Cup match, West Ham United secured a 2-0 victory over Cheltenham Town. The first half saw West Ham take control with two quick goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew. Cheltenham, who remained unchanged from their recent 3-0 league defeat, had opportunities through Harry Pell's volley and Jordon Forster's header, but couldn't capitalize. West Ham, making seven changes following losses to Manchester United and Southampton, could have extended their lead with attempts from James Collins and Sam Byram. Cheltenham's best chance came when Dan Holman narrowly missed connecting with Pell's low volley. The match ended with West Ham's 2-0 win, marking Cheltenham's exit from the EFL Cup and ending League Two's representation in the competition.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer and father of four, tragically lost his life in a car accident on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion. The collision occurred when Andreas Werner, a 46-year-old man from Leipzig, failed to notice McNicholl on his motorcycle as Werner turned his VW Transporter right. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates' Court. He was fined £1,000 and received a two-year driving ban in the UK. The victim's family, while acknowledging it was a momentary lapse, expressed no desire for Werner to be imprisoned. Werner, who was staying in a cottage near Bala with his family, was described as remorseful and unable to explain the incident.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old British man from Southall, London, attempted to return to the UK last year after being a prominent British fighter in Syria. Known as Abu Daigham al-Britani, he was a member of Rayat al Tawheed, an Islamic State-affiliated group that produced slick propaganda to attract British recruits. Khawaja's activities in Syria, while online and masked, included posting videos and pictures of his jihad, participating in appeals for donations, and creating propaganda content. His group was known for its dynamic approach, using cultural references to appeal to young British Muslims. However, their content also included gruesome scenes of violence.

Khawaja decided to return to the UK in June, with his cousin Tahir Bhatti assisting him. To avoid detection, Khawaja faked his own death online. Upon their arrival at Dover, they were met by the police and faced prosecution at the Old Bailey. Khawaja admitted to four offenses, while Bhatti pleaded guilty to assisting an offender. Initially, Khawaja was charged with soliciting to murder, but this charge was later dropped. He was held in a high-risk terrorism unit at Belmarsh prison due to his perceived danger. The exact reasons for his return and future plans remain unclear.

Kayden Jackson, a 22-year-old footballer, has signed with Barnsley for the upcoming season. Last season, Jackson played for Wrexham, scoring four goals in 36 appearances, contributing to their eighth-place finish. Jackson's pace and defensive-attacking style of play align well with Barnsley's strategy, as noted by caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom. Notably, Jackson declined a contract offer from Wrexham for the next season. This signing comes before Barnsley's League One play-off final against an unspecified opponent at Wembley on Sunday.

Volunteers from the National Trust have been clearing bottles of 'Vanish' detergent from beaches around Poldhu Cove on the Lizard, Cornwall, since Sunday. These bottles are believed to have leaked from a container that fell overboard from a ship, possibly the MV Blue Ocean, during stormy weather near Land's End in May. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency confirmed that the MV Blue Ocean lost a container of 'Vanish' bottles, but the evidence linking these bottles to the ship is currently circumstantial. The Cornwall Wildlife Trust expressed concern over the potential impact on marine life. The National Trust is managing the cleanup, and the public is advised to keep children and dogs away from the bottles. Cornwall Council and other agencies are monitoring the situation.

A car crash happened on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness around 14:00. The crash resulted in serious injuries to one individual and minor injuries to several others. The road was subsequently closed, and diversions were established via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland stated that their inquiries into the incident are still ongoing.

Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, has signed a new contract with Bolton Wanderers. Dervite joined the club from Charlton in 2014 and has since made 83 appearances in all competitions. Despite being somewhat overlooked during the initial part of the last season, he made 14 appearances towards the end, contributing significantly to Wanderers' second-place finish in League One and their subsequent promotion to the Championship. Manager Phil Parkinson praised Dervite's contributions, noting that he was a "forgotten man" who made an "excellent contribution" towards the end of the season. Dervite is the fourth player to sign a new contract with Bolton following their promotion, joining David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan.

The passage describes a disagreement between the Liberal Democrats (Lib Dems) and Labour in the UK Parliament, specifically in the House of Lords. The Lib Dems, led by Lord Oates, accused Labour of being willing to "concede everything" and giving people "false hope". This tension arose after Labour and the Lib Dems collaborated to defeat government amendments on the rights of EU citizens and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal. However, when these amendments were rejected by MPs, the Lib Dems persisted in insisting on them, while Labour chose to support the government.

A Labour source criticized the Lib Dems for "grandstanding" and raising false hopes among people anxious about their future in Britain. In response, the Lib Dems' Europe spokesperson, Baroness Ludford, accused Labour of "waving through the government's plans" and aligning with the Conservatives for a hard Brexit.

The passage also highlights a history of cooperation between the two parties on various issues, including higher education and housing bills. Despite this, Baroness Ludford expressed optimism about future collaboration, while a Labour source predicted "residual tensions" and doubted the likelihood of further joint efforts.

In the current election, defense is a low priority for most political parties, ranking far behind economic, healthcare, and immigration concerns. This lack of emphasis is reflected in the minimal detail provided in Labour and Conservative manifestos regarding defense policies. The UK's military capabilities are being significantly reduced, with the Army shrinking from 102,000 to 82,000, the Royal Navy's fleet decreasing to 19 warships, and the RAF's front-line fast jet squadrons dropping to eight (soon to be seven). The UK has also fallen from fourth to sixth in global defense spending, and is projected to fall below the NATO threshold of 2% of GDP spent on defense by the end of the decade.

The military faces capability gaps, such as the lack of Maritime Patrol Aircraft, forcing reliance on NATO allies for submarine surveillance. The Conservatives, Labour, and Lib Dems have not committed to protecting defense spending, with the MoD's £34bn annual budget being vulnerable to further cuts. The Trident nuclear deterrent renewal is a contentious issue, with the Conservatives and UKIP committed to a like-for-like replacement, while Labour and the Liberal Democrats propose variations.

The UK's two new aircraft carriers, the Queen Elizabeth and Prince of Wales, symbolize global ambition but face crewing challenges and scaled-down F-35 jet plans. The military's ability to "punch above its weight" is increasingly questioned due to these reductions and constraints.

Barcelona, the Spanish champions, have made an additional tax payment of 13.55 million euros regarding the transfer of Neymar from Santos. The club insists they have not committed any offense, stating the payment is to cover potential interpretations of the contracts involved in the transfer. The total cost of Neymar to Barcelona, including the initial fee, signing-on fee, wages, agents' fees, and this latest tax payment, amounts to £106.8 million. The club's former president, Sandro Rosell, resigned last month amid accusations of misappropriating funds related to the transfer, which he denies. A Spanish judge has ruled there is enough evidence to continue investigating the transfer. Despite the payment, it is unclear if the case will be closed. Neymar, who has scored 14 goals in 25 appearances for Barcelona this season, has not commented on the situation.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old father from Nottingham, tragically died in a motorway accident caused by Albert Kenneth Newman, who was driving the wrong way in his Mazda Premacy. Luciw's family, devastated by the loss, emphasized the need for regular driving tests for older drivers, suggesting a test in a car with a driving instructor to accurately assess driving abilities. They argue that as people age, their reactions slow down, and this could be mitigated by such tests. Luciw's brother, Simon, and colleague, Andy Harrington, who survived the crash with serious injuries, also advocated for mandatory medical examinations for retired drivers. The incident occurred at 02:00 GMT on 12 October near Kegworth, Leicestershire, when Newman's car collided with the van driven by Harrington. Harrington, who hadn't seen Newman's car until the last second, expressed his ongoing trauma from the event.

Currently, drivers over 70 in the UK must complete a self-assessment form every three years to renew their licenses, which does not include a medical or driving test. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) maintains that evidence does not indicate older drivers are more prone to causing serious accidents. Age UK, however, stresses the importance of supporting older drivers to maintain safe driving practices for as long as possible. The DVLA removes driving privileges if a driver is found medically unfit. The family of Michael Luciw continues to advocate for stricter driving regulations for older drivers to prevent similar tragedies.

The passage discusses concerns over the safety of transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence and pelvic organ prolapse in women. Two members of the original review group resigned, protesting against a perceived watered-down final report. An independent expert, Professor Alison Britton, has been tasked to examine the review process and identify lessons for the future. The final report recommends against routine use of these procedures, advocating instead for a range of treatment options and informed patient choices. It also calls for mandatory reporting of adverse events. Despite calls for a complete ban, the Scottish government, lacking the power to do so, will continue implementing these recommendations. The chairwoman of the independent review, Tracey Gillies, apologized for failing to unite all panel members around the final report. Two panel members, Olive McIlroy and Elaine Holmes, resigned due to dissatisfaction with the report, alleging parts were removed. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have undergone this surgery over the past 20 years, with more than 400 currently pursuing legal action due to complications.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old British athlete, broke Jenny McColgan's 25-year-old 5000m record at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow, completing the race in 14 minutes and 49.12 seconds, 14 seconds faster than McColgan's previous record. McColgan expressed excitement about her record being broken but raised concerns about whether Muir's race met all the criteria for a record-breaking attempt, specifically questioning if it was a "genuine race" and if doping control was in place. British Athletics confirmed that Muir's time would be ratified as official, noting that doping control is not required for British records unless specified. McColgan praised Muir's potential, stating that she could potentially run the 5000m in 14.30 minutes and compete for world medals. Muir's race, where she lapped other runners, mirrored McColgan's own record-breaking race 25 years ago. McColgan also noted that it was a bonus to see her record broken by a fellow Scot, recognizing Muir's world-class abilities and potential for future success.

In the Rio Olympics, Germany's Michael Jung won the gold medal in equestrian eventing, riding Sam, who replaced Fischertakinou due to an infection. France's Nicolas Astier secured silver, and American Phillip Dutton took bronze. Britain's William Fox-Pitt, a three-time Olympic medallist, finished 12th. Fox-Pitt, who was in an induced coma 10 months prior due to a fall, had a faultless show-jumping phase but a poor cross-country phase, leading to a significant drop in ranking. Ireland's Jonty Evans placed ninth. The passage also mentions the availability of Henry, a mechanical horse, at Team GB fan parks during the Rio Olympics, and encourages readers to subscribe to the BBC Sport newsletter for more updates and guides on equestrian sports.

Andy Murray, a 30-year-old British tennis player, secured his place in the fourth round of Wimbledon after a challenging match against Italy's Fabio Fognini. The match lasted two hours and 39 minutes, with Murray winning 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5. Fognini, the 29th seed, had five set points to force a fifth set, but Murray managed to win five consecutive games to clinch victory at 20:57 BST. The match was tense, with Murray stating it was an "up and down" game, and the conditions became challenging as the light faded. Fognini, who had an ankle injury, showed both his talent and temperamental side, while Murray's fighting qualities were evident as he saved multiple set points. Murray will face French player Benoit Paire in the next round. Earlier, fellow British player Johanna Konta also advanced to the second week for the first time, defeating Maria Sakkari of Greece. Murray expressed satisfaction with his progress, acknowledging his need to improve his movement and prepare for future matches.

On 6 October 2014, paramedics were dispatched to Joe's Bar in Dungiven following a sudden death at 06:00 BST. Police arrived shortly after, discovering patrons still present and till receipts indicating alcohol sales until 04:49 BST. The court ordered the bar's closure for three months. Colleen O'Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, both from Kevin Lynch Park, were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. O'Neill faced two counts, while Thomas faced one. The defense solicitor stated that licensing laws in Dungiven were not strictly followed, and the premises were operating beyond legal hours. The judge, noting O'Neill's "appalling record," expressed concern over his inability to impose a custodial sentence. O'Neill was fined £3,000, and Thomas was fined £1,000.

Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionist Party, launched his party's manifesto with a focus on partnership over domination. He emphasized that the election should serve as a referendum on the mishandling of the Renewable Heat Incentive (RHI) scandal. However, the attention has shifted to the Ulster Unionists following Nesbitt's comments. Nesbitt addressed the public distancing of his colleague, Danny Kennedy, from his remarks, stating it was reaffirming rather than disappointing. He firmly denied any regrets or mistakes, reiterating his stance on voting for Ulster Unionists and other candidates who will act in the community's best interest.

Nesbitt expressed his preference for partnering with the SDLP over Sinn Féin if the Ulster Unionists were to enter Stormont Castle. He reported receiving positive feedback during his door-to-door campaigning in unionist areas, despite the ongoing controversy over his remarks. The manifesto, titled 'Real Partnership', outlines plans to tackle waiting lists, increase PSNI numbers, prioritize the York Street interchange, support the LGBT community, and ensure no group is negatively impacted by Brexit.

In the 'Cleaning Up Stormont' section, the party calls for action against incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and corruption. Nesbitt hopes this message will resonate more strongly than the ongoing debate about his comments on potentially transferring votes to the SDLP.

Northern Ireland's Justice Minister, Claire Sugden, has announced a motion to be presented to the assembly for approval. This motion aligns Northern Ireland with England and Wales, where plans for automatic pardons for men convicted of now-abolished sexual offenses were recently introduced. Known as 'Turing's Law', after Alan Turing, the law will grant posthumous pardons to deceased men and allow living men convicted of such offenses to apply for pardons. The motion in the assembly will include similar provisions, enabling pardons for both posthumous and living gay and bisexual men. Sugden has secured executive agreement to request the assembly to pass a legislative consent motion to pardon convictions related to abolished sexual offenses. She emphasized the need for equal treatment of gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland, similar to their counterparts in England and Wales. The minister aims to implement these arrangements as soon as possible to rectify past injustices, bypassing the lengthier process of an assembly bill. The motion is now under consideration by the assembly.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old athlete from Kinross, has set a new Scottish record in the women's 1500m race, finishing second behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon with a time of 4 minutes, 19.12 seconds. This performance surpasses Yvonne Murray's 1994 record of 4:22.60 and places Muir second on the British all-time list, behind Zola Budd's record of 4:17.57. Muir, who recently won the 800m in Montbeliard, France, expressed her satisfaction with her performance, noting it as her first race of the season over this distance. She aims to secure an Olympic spot for Great Britain at the British trials in Birmingham from June 24-26. Muir, who is currently in her fourth year of veterinary school, plans to compete next in a 1500m race in Stockholm.

The passage presents a collection of images from 26 beaches in Scotland that have been recognized for their exceptional water quality. These beaches have been ranked as some of the best in the country based on water quality standards.

Barrister Richard Horwell QC, representing the Met Police, stated that suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive to kill Alexander Litvinenko, a former Russian officer who defected to the UK in 2000. Horwell suggested that the Russian state was likely the sponsor of the plot, citing numerous reasons for the state to want Litvinenko "not only harmed, but dead." Litvinenko was poisoned with polonium-210 during a meeting with Kovtun and Lugovoi in London in 2006, leading to his death three weeks later. Horwell emphasized that the use of polonium indicated Russian state involvement, though he clarified that this did not implicate President Vladimir Putin. Litvinenko's defection and subsequent criticism of Putin were cited as potential motives. Horwell also noted that Litvinenko was likely poisoned twice before his death and that the public risk from polonium radiation remains unknown. The suspects, who deny any wrongdoing, left a trail of polonium and provided no credible explanation for the scientific evidence against them. Extradition attempts have failed, and they remain in Russia. Former Soviet army officer Kovtun was criticized for not providing evidence to the inquiry.

Steve Smith, a 26-year-old batsman, has been appointed as the permanent captain of the Australian cricket team, succeeding Michael Clarke, who retired after a heavy defeat in the Ashes series against England. Smith, highly regarded by the selectors, had previously captained the team in three Tests against India last summer while Clarke was recovering from injuries. He has played 32 Tests, scoring 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66. David Warner, 28, has been named as Smith's vice-captain, despite past disciplinary issues. Warner has matured into a significant senior figure in the team, and the selectors believe he will handle the added responsibility well. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in the limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test at the Oval, starting on 20 August.

Tim Farron, the newly elected leader of the UK's Liberal Democrats, expressed his support for LGBT-plus rights and equal marriage, stating these issues would be a priority for him. He refused to answer whether he believes homosexual sex is a sin, instead emphasizing that "we are all sinners". Farron voted against the Equality Bill in 2007 due to concerns about individual liberties, though he did not specify what those concerns were. He also expressed a desire to extend marital rights to transgender people, particularly addressing the issue of the spousal veto, which currently prevents transgender individuals from marrying without their spouse's consent. Despite his past vote, Farron affirmed his commitment to equal access under law for all people, regardless of their sexuality.

Sanofi, a French pharmaceutical company, shut down its manufacturing site in Fawdon in 2015, resulting in 450 job losses. However, Accord Healthcare, a global pharmaceutical firm, has now acquired the plant for production purposes. Accord Healthcare is optimistic that many of the former Sanofi employees will be rehired. Newcastle City Council leader, Councillor Nick Forbes, praised the development, stating it strengthens the region's reputation in the science and healthcare sector. Accord Healthcare, known for its production of over 130 pharmaceutical products distributed to around 60 countries, is expected to bring significant economic benefits to the local area through job creation and long-term investment.

Richard Ellis, the council's former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, is leaving on Friday at the end of his contract. Ciaran Monaghan, head of the chief executive's office, and Ewan Sutherland, head of human resources and customer services, are departing under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Stephen Flynn, leader of the opposition SNP group, attributes these departures to the council's struggle in retaining senior staff, predicting more departures in the near future. Council chief executive Angela Scott expressed gratitude to the trio for their dedication and professionalism.

English rider John Martin, after a crash at this year's TT and ongoing mechanical issues with his Fireblade bike, announced his departure from road racing. However, he later clarified on Facebook that he is not entirely giving up on racing, but has no immediate plans to participate in more road racing events on Hondas this year. Martin skipped the North West 200 due to a team-mate's crash and will not compete in the upcoming Ulster Grand Prix. He described the TT as a "bloody disaster," noting that the bike was not competitive and he was essentially functioning as a test rider. Following further testing at Cadwell, the team decided to withdraw him from the Ulster Grand Prix. Martin expressed interest in racing classics and unusual events in the future.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured a significant victory in Nigeria's recent gubernatorial elections, winning 19 out of 28 governor posts. This marks a substantial defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), which has been in power for 16 years. The APC's leader, Muhammadu Buhari, who defeated President Goodluck Jonathan in the presidential election, will be inaugurated on May 29. The PDP's decline was evident in key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, and they lost control of Adamawa, a state affected by Boko Haram's insurgency. However, they retained Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The PDP managed to win eight governorships, mostly in the south-east, with Taraba's result still pending and Imo's election declared inconclusive due to spoilt ballots.

The APC's victory has relegated the PDP to a regional party, with most northern states and Lagos, Nigeria's commercial hub, going to the APC. However, the APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could pose a challenge for President-elect Buhari due to potential disruptions in oil production by militant groups.

The elections, while marred by some violence, were generally more peaceful than in previous years, indicating a maturing of Nigeria's democracy. The PDP's loss is attributed to voter dissatisfaction with their 16-year rule, characterized by allegations of corruption and failure to address the insurgency in the north-east. The party will need to undergo introspection and rebuild under new leadership.

The passage discusses allegations made by the US-based environmental lobby group Mighty against Olam, a Singapore-based agricultural commodities trader. Mighty accuses Olam and its main stakeholder, Temasek, of supporting unsustainable palm oil practices that contribute to haze caused by slash-and-burn activities in Indonesia. Olam denies these claims, stating it has a strict 'no burn-no peat-no deforestation' policy and that its suppliers comply with these standards. However, Mighty asserts that Olam created a "secretive market for rogue palm oil companies." Olam has agreed to disclose the names of its 14 suppliers, but the verification process will take years. Temasek, the majority stakeholder in Olam, dismisses the allegations, asserting support for no-burn policies. The report also highlights Olam's activities in Gabon, where it is accused of clearing rainforests for palm oil plantations. Olam counters that these projects are transparent and responsible. The palm oil industry is globally significant but often criticized for environmental damage, labor issues, and deforestation. The core issue revolves around the responsibility of companies like Olam in ensuring sustainable practices in their supply chains and the challenges in enforcing such standards.

On August 27, 2016, a restaurant started offering "puppy platters" following a new law permitting dogs to dine at outdoor restaurant areas. The passage includes a reference to a video clip showcasing the unusual menu.

Fernando Forestieri, a forward for the team, is uncertain to play due to a knee injury, having only been able to participate as a substitute in the last two matches. David Nugent, a striker for Derby County, might be available again after missing the recent draw with Huddersfield due to a groin issue. Jacob Butterfield, a midfielder, is optimistic about regaining his starting position after scoring a late equalizer against Huddersfield while coming on as a substitute.

Pakistan's telecoms regulator, the Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA), has lifted the ban on YouTube, which was imposed in 2012 following the upload of the US-made film "Innocence of Muslims". The film, which mocked the Prophet Muhammad, sparked widespread protests and violence in Pakistan. The ban was lifted after Google introduced a Pakistan-specific version of YouTube. The PTA has directed all internet service providers to open access to YouTube. Google has also provided a process for the PTA to request the removal of offending material directly. However, YouTube maintains that it will only remove content that violates its community guidelines and will record any government requests for content removal in its Transparency Report. Some activists in Pakistan are calling for more transparency regarding the terms of the deal between Google and the government.

Domenico Scala, head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is Swiss-Italian, like one of the five presidential candidates, Gianni Infantino. Scala stepped down from the 2015 elections due to his shared nationality with candidate Sepp Blatter. Musa Bility, head of the Liberian Football Association, has threatened to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by a specified date. Bility argues that Scala's presence on the committee creates a conflict of interest, citing Fifa's Electoral Regulations. However, Scala's spokesman, Andreas Bantel, contends that having the same nationality as a candidate does not constitute a conflict of interest, as per Fifa's regulations. Bility emphasizes the importance of fairness and integrity in the electoral process following Fifa's recent turmoil. The election, which will replace long-standing president Blatter, is scheduled for 26 February and will be conducted by Fifa's 209 members in Zurich. The candidates vying for the position are Prince Ali, Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman, and Tokyo Sexwale, in addition to Infantino.

Two men, Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were fatally killed at Harford Attachments, a company in Spar Road that manufactures buckets for diggers. The incident occurred around 09:00 BST on Monday in a paint-spraying area. Their bodies were recovered on Tuesday afternoon. A forensic search was conducted at the site. Detective Chief Inspector Paul Durham stated that the evidence suggests a flashover explosion, caused by a build-up of toxic fumes and an ignition source, resulting in a fireball. The Health and Safety Executive is involved in the investigation, focusing on evidence gathering and electrical safety aspects.

Tunisia and Morocco faced significant challenges leading up to the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations. Tunisia was initially at risk of being disqualified from the 2017 tournament due to complaints lodged against the Confederation of African Football (Caf) following a controversial quarter-final match against Equatorial Guinea in the 2015 tournament. The Tunisian Football Federation (FTF) criticized the referee's decision to award a penalty in the 90th minute, which they believed was unjustified and influenced by the stadium atmosphere. Contrary to media reports, the FTF did not accuse Caf or the referee of corruption, but rather questioned the suitability of the referee for the match.

After a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou in Senegal, Tunisia managed to resolve their differences with Caf, and their participation in the 2017 tournament was secured. Morocco, on the other hand, was initially banned from the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw due to their refusal to host the 2015 tournament, citing Ebola fears. The Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) later overturned this ban and reduced the fine imposed on Morocco's FA from $1m to $50,000.

Both Tunisia and Morocco will participate in the 2017 tournament. Tunisia has been placed in Group A, where they will face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti. Morocco is in Group F, alongside Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome. If Tunisia qualifies for the finals, they will set a record by reaching their thirteenth consecutive Nations Cup.

In a match at Etihad Stadium, Chelsea defeated Manchester City 3-1. The game escalated into a mass fracas in the 95th minute, leading to the dismissals of Manchester City's forward Sergio Aguero and midfielder Fernandinho. Aguero, who has a history of violent conduct this season, received a four-match ban for a high and late challenge on Chelsea defender David Luiz. Fernandinho, involved in a subsequent altercation with Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas, will serve a three-match ban. Despite the incident, Chelsea's Fabregas will not face further action. Manchester City's manager, Pep Guardiola, apologized for his team's involvement. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

Wales and other regions, such as Denmark, are leading in early detection of certain types of cancer worldwide. A pilot program in Cwm Taf region, specifically in Cwm Cynon and Castell-nedd, focuses on patients whose family medical history indicates cancer risk but shows no symptoms or signs. This initiative was inspired by a visit to Denmark last year to observe their diagnostic systems. Health board officials noted Denmark's improved cancer detection rates. However, in Wales, patients without clear symptoms often face long diagnostic periods, as they are not "easy" to route through specific treatment paths. This delay can lead many patients to start treatment after their cancer has progressed or when it's incurable. 

Approximately 40 general practitioners in Cwm Cynon believe that some patients might benefit from referral to a diagnostic center in the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital, Llantrisant, within seven days. The plan aims to see and provide different opinions for about seven patients weekly. Currently, only 35% of patients with "peripheral" symptoms in Cwm Taf region receive diagnoses. Doctors aim to reach the most patients without obvious symptoms. A similar clinic will be established in Castell-nedd Port Talbot Hospital as part of another pilot program by Abertawe Bro Morgannwg Health Board.

The diagnostic centers were developed over the past 12 months after Danish experts returned to Wales. Denmark was chosen due to its advanced cancer detection rates. According to Dr. Gareth Davies, Cancer Care Network Director for Wales, the plan will simplify the process and accelerate diagnosis. "If the family doctor sees a patient with a suspicion but uncertainty, they can refer the patient directly to the clinician, indicating the patient will be seen promptly and hopefully diagnosed."

Dr. Gareth Jordan, a family doctor in Aberdâr, believes the pilot program could significantly improve patient experiences. "They could say, 'I've seen this man, he's lost a lot of weight... he might not need to go to a specialist clinic or if the specialist's appointment is far away, the specialist could provide the service here

England secured a dominant victory over Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series. England declared their first innings at 589-8 and their second at 173-1, resulting in a second-largest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root, promoted to number three for this series, was the standout performer, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second. He also took four catches and claimed a wicket. Root's performance was praised by captain Alastair Cook and former England batsman Geoffrey Boycott. Pakistan's batting struggled, with only captain Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq passing 50 in the first two Tests. Their spirits were described as broken, with poor shot selection and lack of confidence cited as major issues. The third Test is set to begin on 3 August at Edgbaston. Despite the win, Vaughan predicted a tight series.

Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand, with Rob Howley as part of his backroom team. Forwards coach Robin McBryde, who has previously led Wales on tours in 2009 and 2013, will assume head coach responsibilities for the third time. McBryde expressed his honor and excitement about the role. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour to support McBryde. The WRU's chief executive, Martyn Phillips, stated that discussions are at an advanced stage with other individuals for the tour, with a full team confirmation expected next week. Union chairman Gareth Davies, also on the Lions' selection panel, believes this involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit the national team, providing an opportunity for development and inspiration for both coaches and players.

Hull City secured their first league win since August 20, ending a six-game losing streak, by defeating Southampton 2-1. The match, held at the KCOM Stadium, saw Hull struggle initially, losing two strikers, Abel Hernandez and Will Keane, to injuries early in the game. However, the introduction of Robert Snodgrass from the bench transformed the game. Snodgrass, despite a swollen ankle, provided the spark Hull needed, scoring a goal and assisting another for Michael Dawson. Southampton, who had taken an early lead through Charlie Austin's penalty, pushed for an equalizer but were thwarted by Hull's goalkeeper David Marshall's string of saves. The winning goal came from Snodgrass's inviting free-kick, which Dawson headed in. The match also saw a remarkable goalline clearance from Hull's Sam Clucas in the final minute of added time. The victory, though, did not lift Hull out of the relegation zone, but it provided a much-needed morale boost heading into the international break. Southampton's manager, Claude Puel, acknowledged the team's lack of concentration and the difficulty of maintaining form after a European game, while Hull's manager, Mike Phelan, praised his players' character and the performance of goalkeeper David Marshall.

A motorcycle crash occurred on the B1191 near Woodhall Spa, Lincolnshire, at approximately 14:15 BST. The incident involved a motorcyclist who was locally resident and unfortunately lost their life, though no further details have been disclosed. The tractor driver involved in the collision was unharmed. Lincolnshire Police have requested witnesses to come forward. As a result of the accident, the B1191 was shut down in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

Macedonian President Gjorge Ivanov has terminated an investigation into allegations of abuse of power, stemming from covert recordings released in 2015. These recordings, which have been a source of turmoil in the country, allegedly reveal ministers plotting vote-rigging and covering up a murder. The opposition leader, Zoran Zaev, has been releasing these recordings since February 2015, accusing the government of wiretapping 20,000 individuals, including politicians, journalists, and religious leaders. Zaev claims the recordings expose corruption, mismanagement of funds, and even cover-ups of killings. However, the government denies these allegations and accuses Zaev of attempting to destabilize the nation. Ivanov's decision to halt the investigation aims to "defend national interests" and "put an end to the agony," ahead of the June early elections. This move has been widely condemned by the opposition and EU officials, including Johannes Hahn, who stated that it jeopardizes Macedonia's EU membership aspirations and is not in line with the rule of law.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will manage Swansea's match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's dismissal. The club aims to appoint a new head coach promptly, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement as the preferred candidate. The passage highlights the club's current struggle and the possibility of relegation, emphasizing the difficulty of returning to the Premier League due to the strengthened Championship. Curtis, a former player, believes Swansea has lost its identity since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014, with frequent management changes diluting the 'Swansea Way'. Despite this, Curtis is confident that the current squad, aware of the club's history and the importance of staying in the Premier League, is capable of avoiding relegation.

Dagenham & Redbridge were relegated from League Two after losing to Leyton Orient, a defeat that kept Orient's play-off hopes alive. The match saw Orient take a 2-0 lead with goals from Jay Simpson, while Dagenham fought back with goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona. However, Armand Gnanduillet's winning goal sealed Dagenham's fate. Dagenham, who reached League One for the first time in 2007 under manager John Still, now return to the National League. The club has struggled this season with the worst goal difference in League Two, conceding 20 more goals than at the same point last season. Their attack has also been weak, with 40-year-old striker Jamie Cureton scoring only nine goals this season, compared to 20 the previous season. Despite the relegation, Still remains committed to promoting Dagenham back to League One next season. Orient, on the other hand, now sit two points behind the play-off spots following the interim management of Andy Hessenthaler, who took over from Kevin Nolan. Both managers acknowledged the challenges their teams faced, with Hessenthaler emphasizing the need for Orient to win games to secure a play-off spot, and Still highlighting Dagenham's lack of organization and discipline as reasons for their relegation.

Steven Gerrard, the former Liverpool captain and 36-year-old ex-England player, is set to return to his former club as a youth coach in February. This marks his first role since retiring as a player in November, concluding a 19-year career that included winning the Champions League, Uefa Cup, FA Cup, and League Cup three times each. Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp expressed enthusiasm about Gerrard's appointment, noting his ambition to become a manager in the future and his readiness to learn. Gerrard is currently pursuing his Uefa A coaching licence, a prerequisite for managing in the Premier League. He was previously linked with the manager's position at MK Dons but deemed it "too soon".

Morton secured a comfortable win against Alloa, with the scoring initiated by McManus in the 15th minute. Forbes' deflected shot soon extended Morton's lead. Alloa managed to narrow the gap with a goal from Kyle McAusland before halftime. McManus scored again in the second half, followed by a late goal from Denny Johnstone, solidifying Morton's victory.

Ofsted, the UK's school inspectorate, has uncovered evidence of children being taught in poor conditions in three unregistered schools in Birmingham, which have since been shut down. The operators of these schools could face up to 51 weeks in jail. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Ofsted's Chief Inspector, expressed shock at the conditions and concern that children might be at risk of abuse or radicalization. The investigation, which has visited 18 unregulated schools, mainly in Muslim communities in the Midlands, revealed that these schools often operate beyond the legal limit of 20 hours a week, exploiting the legal right to home educate. Sir Michael criticized the government's officials for providing confusing advice to the proprietors. The government has allocated funding for a team of six inspectors to investigate illegal schools, and the Education Secretary has instructed Ofsted to prepare cases for prosecution against unregistered schools. The consultation on further regulation is ongoing until mid-January. Sir Michael emphasized that the crackdown will apply to all religious groups, not just Muslim communities.

Lilliard Gin, located at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, Scotland, is set to become the region's first whisky distillery since 1837. The distillery, led by Kate Macinnes, aims to produce gin on a unique scale using a small production still, the smallest in the UK. The gin is designed to encapsulate the local flavours of the Teviot valley, reflecting the region's 'terroir'. The distillery's name, Lilliard, honors a legendary Borders figure who was the heroine of the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545. The distillery's focus on local sourcing aligns with the Born in the Borders ethos, and it is expected to contribute to making the Scottish Borders a region of distilling excellence.

Gary Green, 51, from Wakefield, was jailed for 16 months and two weeks for recklessly reversing a tractor into Harry Whitlam, 20, at Swithens Farm, Rothwell, near Leeds, in August 2013. Green was more than twice the legal driving limit, having consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before going to bed. The incident occurred in a closed-off area of the farm, leading to Green being prosecuted under health and safety legislation rather than road traffic law. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed her family's devastation, stating that Harry was a beloved son, brother, grandson, nephew, and cousin. She emphasized the dangers of drunk driving, whether on public roads or private land. The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) described Green's behavior as "reckless" in this "extremely tragic case."

Uruguay striker Luis Suarez, 27, has been cleared by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) to train and participate in friendly matches with his new club, Barcelona. However, he still faces an eight-game ban in competitive international games and will miss Barcelona's first match after the ban, El Clasico against Real Madrid on 26 October. Suarez can now join Barcelona's training sessions and attend matches, but he cannot play in organized games, including friendlies, until his ban is lifted. He will be available for Uruguay's friendlies against Japan, South Korea, and Saudi Arabia. The Cas upheld most of Fifa's sanctions, including the nine-match ban, but deemed the total ban from football-related activities as excessive. Suarez's legal team argued that Fifa's punishment was disproportionate, and Cas agreed that any sanction should be proportionate. Suarez has a history of disciplinary issues, including biting incidents and a racial abuse suspension.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won the World Hurdles Race on 18 March 2014, outpacing Vytautas Kirkliauskas of Lithuania and his wife Neringa Kirliauskiene. The race, which covers a 380-metre course, involves hurdling over haystacks, climbing a steep slope, and avoiding water pistols. The event is open to all combinations of competitors, including men carrying men and women carrying women. The winning team, Richard and Anna, had trained for a week by running around a local athletics track. They will now represent the UK at the World Championships in Finland in July.

In October 2014, the UK government plans to replace the paper car tax disc system with an electronic direct debit system. This change, announced by Chancellor George Osborne in his Autumn Statement, has raised concerns about potential job losses among the 5,000 employees at the Driving and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) in Swansea. However, Minister Stephen Hammond addressed these fears in a letter to Swansea East AM Mike Hedges. Hammond acknowledged that the new system might lead to a reduction in refund-related jobs and necessitate changes in job roles. He assured that any job reductions would be managed through redeployment to other growth areas within the DVLA, rather than redundancies. Hedges, while disappointed about the potential reduction in job opportunities, welcomed Hammond's commitment to redeployment and expressed confidence that this would comfort concerned DVLA employees. The new system will allow vehicle owners to pay their tax charges via monthly direct debits, eliminating the need to display a physical tax disc.

Hungary's Foreign Minister, Peter Szijjarto, has stated that the EU should not interfere with Hungary's domestic issues, specifically the controversial laws on asylum seekers, higher education, and non-governmental organizations (NGOs). These laws have drawn criticism from the EU, with concerns that they could lead to the closure of the Central European University, founded by George Soros, and potentially violate EU law by housing asylum seekers in secured shipping containers. Thousands of Hungarians have protested these laws. Poland has expressed support for Hungary, with its government stating it would veto any EU sanctions against Hungary. The Fidesz government, led by Prime Minister Viktor Orban, is under pressure from EU institutions to withdraw these laws, but Szijjarto maintains that these issues fall under national competence and the EU should not interfere.

In March 2017, Disney's live-action adaptation of "Beauty and the Beast" will be released in US cinemas. Emma Watson will portray Belle, Dan Stevens will play the Beast, and Luke Evans will be Gaston. Emily Mortimer has been cast as Mrs. Potts, the teapot, while Kevin Kline will play Maurice, Belle's father. Josh Gad will play LeFou, Gaston's sidekick. The film, directed by Bill Condon, began shooting at Shepperton Studios in May. The original animated version featured Dame Angela Lansbury as Mrs. Potts and Robby Benson as the Beast.

Adrian Gill, a renowned journalist and columnist for the Sunday Times, passed away this morning after battling multiple types of cancer. Known for his wit, dazzling writing, and fearless approach, Gill joined the Sunday Times in 1993 and became its "heart and soul." His final column, reflecting on his diagnosis, will be published in tomorrow's edition. Gill was diagnosed with "the full English" of cancers, which he described as an "embarrassment of offal." Despite his illness, he remained stoical and expressed gratitude for his life.

Gill was celebrated by colleagues and peers for his unique writing style and brilliant mind. Sunday Times editor Martin Ivens described him as "a giant among journalists," while former editor John Witherow praised his ability to never produce a dull sentence. Gill's writing often sparked controversy, with comments about the Welsh, Norfolk, the Isle of Man, and others causing outrage.

Born in Edinburgh in 1954, Gill overcame dyslexia to establish a successful writing career. He studied art in London and began his career with art reviews before moving on to Tatler and the Sunday Times. Gill was married twice, first to author Cressida Connolly and later to current Home Secretary Amber Rudd. He had four children in total. His illness led to his engagement to his long-term partner, Nicola Formby, with whom he had twins.

Gill's death has left a significant void in the journalism world, with colleagues and friends expressing profound sadness and paying tribute to his exceptional talent and kindness.

Rapper Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, known as Amraa, was allegedly attacked during a performance in Ulan Bator, Mongolia's capital. He was reportedly hit over the head with a bottle and repeatedly kicked in the face, resulting in a 10-day coma. The attack occurred while Sukhbaatar was wearing a red deel embroidered with a swastika, a traditional Mongolian symbol that predates Hitler's use of it. The Russian embassy is investigating the incident but disputes local press reports, claiming they are "distorted". The suspect, a Russian diplomatic officer, has not been identified or arrested, despite denials of diplomatic immunity. Sukhbaatar's father and lawyer refute claims that he shouted "Heil Hitler" during the show, emphasizing that the swastika is not a hate symbol in Mongolia. The incident has sparked discussions about the symbol's cultural significance and its misuse by far-right groups in Mongolia.

On Monday, members of the environmental activist group Plane Stupid protested against Heathrow Airport's expansion plans. The demonstration occurred at 3:30 AM BST on the northern runway. As a result, the participants have been charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security-restricted area of the aerodrome. They are scheduled to appear in court on 19 August. In response to the incident, the Metropolitan Police announced a review of security measures at the airport.

Nick Selman's mature 101 off 144 balls, his second first-class century, dominated Glamorgan's total in a match against Gloucestershire. Despite being dropped on eight in the first over, Selman's century marked a welcome return to form after a series of low scores. Aneurin Donald's 36 off 30 balls was the next best contribution from Glamorgan. Gloucestershire's bowlers, Matt Taylor and Craig Miles, remained on top throughout the day, ensuring regular wickets fell in cloudy conditions. Glamorgan managed a consolation bonus point through Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten. Gloucestershire's innings in the evening was a struggle in the gloom, with the day ending evenly balanced. Glamorgan is currently led by Michael Hogan in the absence of Jacques Rudolph due to a neck problem. Selman expressed satisfaction with his knock, while Taylor was pleased with the bowling performance, indicating the challenge ahead for Gloucestershire's batsmen.

Craig Hughes, a 33-year-old man from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August for planning an ambush on police officers. Hughes communicated his intentions to the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee, falsely reporting a crime to lure officers to the Dee Estuary, where he planned to shoot them. He made these threats on two separate occasions while intoxicated. Hughes admitted to two charges at Mold Crown Court and will be sentenced the following week. He has a prior conviction for firearm possession in 2009. Despite his legal team's assertion that Hughes did not intend to carry out the threats or harm himself, the court was particularly concerned due to his pending trial for firearms offenses, for which he was later acquitted. The Hope Line Centre provides confidential support and counseling to individuals facing personal difficulties.

In a crucial match, Surrey overcame Yorkshire's early dominance to secure a win, posting a score of 255-7 after Yorkshire's 236. Surrey's performance was bolstered by a significant partnership of 130 runs between Davies and Ben Foakes, with Foakes scoring 90. Yorkshire's run-chase was disrupted by Stuart Meaker, who took three wickets in nine balls, including those of Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance. Despite Tim Bresnan's 68, Yorkshire fell short, finishing at 236. The match was a setback for Yorkshire, who had recently lost to Durham in the T20 Blast semi-finals. Surrey's captain, Gareth Batty, praised his team's unity and strategic wicket-taking, while Yorkshire's captain, Alex Lees, expressed disappointment, acknowledging the team's struggles in high-stakes situations.

A 56ft trawler, located 6 miles west of South Stack, encountered a situation where its onboard pump failed to manage the incoming water. The crew contacted Holyhead coastguards for assistance at 07:00 BST. The RNLI lifeboat crew responded by deploying a pump and towing the vessel to Holyhead to ensure its safety.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner, has announced she will not be participating in the upcoming Commonwealth Games due to her veterinary medicine studies. Her exams are scheduled for May, clashing with the April Games. Despite her disappointment, she emphasizes the importance of completing her degree. Muir recently competed in the World Athletics Championships, finishing 4th in the 1500m and 6th in the 5000m. Her time in the 5000m race was a new personal best of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds. She expressed her satisfaction with her performance, noting the tough competition. Muir is considering the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target, despite her busy academic schedule. She believes she has potential for future Olympics, though she is unsure about the specific events.

Robbie Savage, in his BBC Sport column, discusses Liverpool's struggles to replicate last season's title challenge. He attributes this to the departure of Luis Suarez, Daniel Sturridge's injuries, and Brendan Rodgers' underwhelming transfer market purchases. The team lacks the same intensity and goal-scoring prowess, with current strikers not meeting the required standards. Additionally, Liverpool's defense, despite Rodgers' efforts to strengthen it, remains inconsistent. Savage predicts a difficult match against Chelsea, with the Blues currently outperforming other teams. He also addresses Steven Gerrard's situation, emphasizing his importance to the team despite his age and the mental challenge of maintaining his high standards. Savage suggests a team lineup for Liverpool against Chelsea, dropping Dejan Lovren and retaining Kolo Toure. Despite these adjustments, he predicts a Chelsea victory due to their current dominance in the league.

A £45 million educational facility is set to be constructed in Kilmarnock, Scotland, at Sutherland Drive. This complex will include primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare center. East Ayrshire Council plans to seek approval from the McIlvanney family to name the campus after the renowned writer, William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock. Council leader Douglas Reid expressed his delight in preserving McIlvanney's legacy, noting his passion for quality education. McIlvanney, a former English teacher, transitioned to full-time writing in 1975, gaining immediate success with his first novel, "Remedy Is None". He is celebrated as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir" for his acclaimed works like the Laidlaw trilogy, "Docherty", and "The Big Man". McIlvanney was also a respected poet, journalist, broadcaster, and political/sporting commentator in Scotland. He passed away on 5 December at his Glasgow residence.

A section of Gourock, near the swimming pool, was evacuated for several hours due to the discovery of a suspected British sea mine from the 1940s or 1950s. The mine was found on Monday, prompting the establishment of an exclusion zone around the river. Residents within 500 meters of the device were advised to stay indoors, keep windows closed, and avoid outdoor activities. A similar exclusion zone was set up at sea, causing disruptions to small boat activities and ferry services operated by Caledonian MacBrayne. The Royal Navy's Northern Diving Unit was tasked with making the mine safe, as its condition made it difficult to determine the amount of explosive material it still held. The evacuation and safety measures were precautionary, with Ch Insp Elliot Brown confirming no immediate danger to the community. Inverclyde Council thanked residents and businesses for their patience during the operation.

UK Sport has allocated a total of £345m to 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for Tokyo 2020, £2m less than the Rio 2016 funding. Sports like archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby were excluded. Cycling, which secured 12 medals in Rio, experienced a £4m funding cut to £25.98m. Badminton, despite achieving a bronze medal in Rio, had its funding removed, a decision criticized by Badminton England's CEO Adrian Christy as "incomprehensible." Judo, which also won a bronze, received a slight funding increase. The funding cuts are part of UK Sport's strategy to prioritize medal potential, with a target set for Team GB to win 51-85 Olympic and 115-162 Paralympic medals. Sports minister Tracey Crouch supported UK Sport's approach, while team sports like basketball, handball, and volleyball criticized the lack of investment in their development. New sports like baseball/softball, karate, skateboard, sports climbing, and surfing will be included in Tokyo 2020, with funding decisions for these yet to be confirmed.

Three Victorian hotels - Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and Ocean View - in Bournemouth's East Cliff conservation area will be demolished to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks. The new development will include a 90-room hotel and 122 assisted-living apartments. Despite English Heritage's strong objection to the scale of the project, citing potential severe harm to the conservation area, Bournemouth councillors voted seven to three in favor, citing the need to preserve tourism and improve living conditions for older residents. The council received 246 letters supporting the plans, while 49 residents and the Ancient Monuments Society objected, arguing that the proposed buildings would eradicate the historic character of the area. The Chair of the planning board, Conservative ward councillor David Kelsey, acknowledged the loss of buildings and trees but emphasized the necessity to move forward and improve the town.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier from Carrickfergus, County Antrim, was fatally beaten by Jake Vallely, 24, in Brecon during a night out on 8 May. The attack occurred outside a bar called The Cellar, where CCTV footage showed Boyd being punched and beaten until he was unconscious. Vallely, who had been drinking for seven hours and boasted about being the "hardest man in Brecon," then dragged Boyd's body away and fled the scene. Aaeron Evans, Vallely's friend, was cleared of manslaughter as he was not present during the attack. The community of Brecon was shocked by the incident, described as "despicable" by the senior investigating officer. Boyd, who served with the Royal Gibraltar Regiment and was in Brecon for training, was remembered by his family as a loving, caring, and joyful individual with a promising career ahead. They expressed their grief, stating that Vallely's actions created an irreplaceable void in their lives. The trial highlighted Vallely's false claim of being the "hardest man in Brecon," contrasted with the community's outpouring of love and support for Boyd's family. Vallely is set to be sentenced on 8 December.

Andrew Travers, the chief executive of Barnet Council, resigned following a significant error on election day where voters were initially turned away from all 155 polling stations due to their names being missing from the poll list. Travers left by "mutual agreement" and praised the changes and growth initiatives during his tenure. The council acknowledged his contributions and appointed Deputy Chief Executive John Hooton as a temporary replacement. The council apologized for the issues, offered emergency proxy votes, and launched an independent investigation into the incident. The review, expected to conclude by the end of May, will examine the appropriateness of arrangements for the upcoming EU Referendum in June. The council is currently discussing who will lead the investigation.

In a football match between Gateshead and Wrexham, Gateshead emerged victorious with a score of 2-1. Josh Gillies gave Gateshead the lead with a well-executed free-kick, but Wrexham equalized before halftime through Sean Newton's set-piece. The decisive goal came in the second half when Ryan Bowman headed in a cross from Craig Baxter. Gateshead's manager, Malcolm Crosby, praised his team's improved second-half performance, particularly their passing accuracy. Conversely, Wrexham's manager, Gary Mills, expressed disappointment, noting his team's defensive lapses in the second half and their inability to capitalize on scoring opportunities. The match saw several fouls and free-kicks, with both teams making substitutions in an attempt to influence the game's outcome.

The Global AgeWatch Index 2014, which evaluates the social and economic well-being of individuals aged 60 and above in 96 countries, ranks Norway as the best and Afghanistan as the worst. Mozambique follows Afghanistan as the second-worst country.
