Stuart Campbell, a Scottish independence campaigner and blogger behind Wings Over Scotland, was arrested in the west of England on Friday following a complaint of online harassment from a woman in her 30s from south London. The alleged harassment occurred over a two-year period, involving tweets from Campbell's account. Campbell, who was released on bail pending further inquiries, denied the allegations, stating that the tweets were not threatening and accused the media of creating "innuendo" to encourage speculation. The Metropolitan Police confirmed they are investigating the allegation of online harassment. Campbell has stated that he will be posting less frequently on his blog due to reasons unrelated to his arrest.

People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA) has proposed replacing Skegness's iconic Jolly Fisherman mascot with a modern, animal-friendly version featuring a fish and the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice". The original Jolly Fisherman poster, commissioned by the Great Northern Railway in 1908, has been a symbol of the Lincolnshire resort, promoting it as a bracing seaside destination. PETA argues that the current mascot evokes images of animal cruelty, referencing practices like fish being impaled and overcrowded in nets. They believe the new suggestion would rebrand Skegness as a progressive holiday destination, not celebrating the mutilation and killing of sea animals. However, Skegness's mayor, Carl Macey, maintains that Jolly is loved and accepted as a friendly and happy figure, and doesn't represent animal cruelty. He suggests that if something isn't broken, there's no need to fix it, implying that the council may not support PETA's proposal.

In a rugby match, Scotland dominated against Georgia, winning with a score of 41-18. Georgia took an early lead through Vasil Lobzhanidze's try, but Scotland quickly overtook with tries from Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, and Stuart Hogg before halftime. Hamish Watson and Hogg scored additional tries in the second half. Georgia responded with two tries of their own, both from Lobzhanidze, but Scotland's superior possession and territory control ensured their victory. The match was marked by Scotland's strong scrum and counter-attacking play, despite Georgia's formidable scrum causing issues. Scotland's head coach, Vern Cotter, praised his team's performance, noting their ability to manage the game and score when necessary. The match also saw several substitutions, including Ali Price's debut, who contributed to Scotland's final try.

Widnes Vikings secured a 38-26 victory over Castleford Tigers in a thrilling match. Widnes took a 14-6 lead at halftime, with tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge. Paddy Flynn, on loan from Widnes to Castleford, scored twice in the second half for Castleford. However, Widnes responded with tries from Ah Van, Lloyd White (2), and Joe Mellor, extending their lead to 38-12. Despite three consecutive tries from Castleford - Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and Flynn's hat-trick - Widnes managed to hold on to their lead. The match saw Castleford's Larne Patrick score just after signing a three-year deal with the club. Widnes' victory moved them above Wakefield into seventh place, while Castleford remained in sixth, one point ahead of Widnes. The defeat marked Castleford's fourth consecutive home league loss.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti, was released from the US detention facility in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, after a review panel determined he was no longer a significant threat. Al-Odah had been held since 2002 on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, claims he denies. He had previously challenged his detention in the US Supreme Court. Upon his release, he boarded a Kuwaiti government plane and expressed no bitterness or anger, only joy at returning home. However, he will spend at least a year in a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait. The Kuwaiti government had been advocating for the release of all Kuwaiti detainees. Al-Odah argued that he traveled to Afghanistan and Pakistan to teach the Koran and provide humanitarian aid. His release, the first since May, reduces the number of inmates at Guantanamo to 148. The facility was established in January 2002 following the 9/11 attacks, and President Obama has pledged to close it.

Anzac Day, commemorating the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One, was celebrated with significant events in London. Thousands gathered for an early morning service at Hyde Park Corner, followed by a parade and wreath-laying at the Cenotaph, where up to 400 people participated. A service was also held at Westminster Abbey, attended by the Australian high commissioner to the UK, Alexander Downer, who laid a wreath and addressed the crowd. The national anthems of New Zealand, Australia, and the UK were sung at the service's conclusion.

The first Anzac Day commemoration in London occurred in 1916, a year after the Anzac landings at Gallipoli, with King George V in attendance. Since then, these services have become crucial for expatriate and visiting New Zealanders and Australians, who honor the sacrifices of their countrymen and women in all wars.

The Gallipoli campaign, an eight-month operation on the peninsula in Turkey, was one of the bloodiest of the war. It was an allied attempt to force the Ottoman Empire out of the conflict. Downer's speech highlighted the courage and heroism of the Anzac troops, ordinary men fighting for various reasons, including their mates, adventure, and a world without war. Veterans, service and ex-service personnel, and their families took part in the parade, with many ex-pats and locals lining the streets to watch the ceremony, which included prayers read by schoolchildren.

Clarkson, a 30-year-old footballer, has rejoined St Mirren in the Championship after a previous stint. He scored nine goals for Dundee last season and has been training diligently to maintain his fitness, despite only featuring as a substitute this term. Clarkson, who has represented Scotland twice and scored once, boasts nearly 400 senior club appearances, having played for teams like Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. He expressed his readiness to play and his ambition to help St Mirren, currently eighth in the Championship, climb the table and improve their standing.

The turkey company, Bernard Matthews, was acquired by food magnate Ranjit Boparan on Tuesday. Initial concerns arose about the new owner potentially disregarding the existing workers' pension scheme. However, Unite regional officer Steve Harley reported positive discussions, receiving assurances that all current agreements, including the pension scheme, would be upheld. The Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme was closed in 2004, and current employees are part of an alternative pension scheme unaffected by the takeover. Boparan's private investment office confirmed the continuation of the existing pension arrangements. Harley met with Boparan representatives at Bernard Matthews' headquarters, where it was emphasized that the new owner aims to restore the company to its former profitability. This would be accomplished through increased investment, cost reductions, and utilizing the current unused capacity at Bernard Matthews for chicken processing, not just turkeys.

The council, led by Dave Stewart, held a scrutiny meeting to address issues with the new chain ferry. The ferry, which launched on May 14, has faced multiple problems including breakdowns, running aground, and suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to training issues. These problems have negatively impacted local businesses, with shopkeeper Angie Booth expressing concern about potential business closure due to lost trade. The council has ordered an auditor review of the project and is considering compensation for affected businesses. Transport councillor Ian Ward acknowledged the teething problems, attributing electrical issues to seamanship, and mentioned that ramp extensions are being manufactured to prevent vehicle damage. The ferry crossing at Cowes will remain free until July 2 to gather feedback and address the issues.

The House of Lords European Union Committee has released a report on the risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry post-Brexit. The report highlights that while the fishing industry contributes only half of one percent to the UK's GDP and employs around 12,000 fishers, it should not be marginalized in Brexit negotiations. The EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), which allows equal access to fishing grounds for all member states, has been criticized by the industry as detrimental to Britain. Many in the fishing community see Brexit as an opportunity to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation.

However, the report warns that continued market access to the EU, which buys most of the UK's fish exports, may come at a cost. This could involve allowing EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters. The report also suggests that many aspects of the CFP should be retained post-Brexit, including scientifically-based quotas and international cooperation obligations.

A potential complication is that leaving the EU could result in four separate fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland. Despite these concerns, many in the fishing industry remain optimistic about Brexit, believing it will bring more opportunities than threats. Recent EU agreement on new fishing quotas, which increased allowable catches for plaice, haddock, and prawns, is seen as a positive sign for the future of British fishing outside the EU. The government has stated its intention to ensure British companies have maximum freedom to trade in the single market while reviewing fisheries management for fair access and sustainability.

Timothy Geaney, a 69-year-old teacher, admitted to taking or permitting the creation of images of young boys in erotic poses between April 2004 and February 2014. These images, mostly depicting partially dressed boys without sexual activity, led to his conviction at Dumfries Sheriff Court. Geaney was initially subjected to a community payback order and placed on the sex offenders register. He was also mandated to participate in a specialized sex offender program.

Following a General Teaching Council Scotland (GTC Scotland) hearing, Geaney was removed from the teaching profession's register due to his offenses. The GTC Scotland panel deemed his actions as condoning and participating in an industry that violates and abuses children, deeming his conduct incompatible with teaching. The panel found that his behavior, which occurred over a prolonged period, demonstrated a pattern rather than an isolated incident.

The panel concluded that there was a strong likelihood of the offending behavior recurring, given the volume of images and duration of the conduct, along with the lack of evidence of remedial action. Geaney was deemed unfit to teach and was prohibited from reapplying for re-registration for a period of two years. He was not present at the GTC Scotland hearing.

On March 2, a fire at Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited's site in Duncan Street led to significant disruptions in train services and travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) subsequently suspended the company from accepting waste. Despite being "broadly compliant" with fire safety laws, the firm was subject to enforcement action due to concerns raised by Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) about potential impacts on nearby residents, transport, and the environment. GMFRS had visited the site nine times in the past year. The EA decided to revoke the company's environmental permit, effective August 7, unless an appeal is filed. The cause of the fire remains unknown. The company, managed by Asset and Land Group, has been ordered to remove all waste from the site.

Syria's Deputy Foreign Minister, Faisal al-Mekdad, stated that Syria is making efforts to comply with the chemical weapons destruction timeline, despite missing the recent deadline. He reported that two shipments were sent to the coast, with the second one being attacked by "terrorist groups." Al-Mekdad criticized the U.S. for condemning the use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, asserting that Syria is defending against "terrorist attacks" and denying the use of civilian areas as targets.

Meanwhile, human rights groups claim that barrel bomb attacks in Aleppo have resulted in hundreds of civilian deaths. The Syrian government denies rebel claims of seizing control of Aleppo's central prison, stating that soldiers thwarted the attack. However, rebel groups assert they now control the prison, which holds at least 3,000 detainees in poor conditions.

Regarding chemical weapons, Syria has approximately 1,300 tonnes of declared stockpiles, with only about 4% (30 tonnes) having left the country so far. The U.S. and Russia have expressed concerns over the slow progress of the UN-backed plan, with Russia urging Syria to complete the transfer by 1 March. The Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW) overseeing the operation, has cited security concerns as the reason for the delays. Al-Mekdad reaffirmed Syria's commitment to its agreements and obligations.

England secured a dominant victory over Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series. England declared their first innings at 589-8 and their second at 173-1, resulting in their second-largest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root, promoted to number three for this series, was named man of the match. He scored 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second, also taking four catches and a wicket. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root's performance, stating it was one of the best Test-match innings he's seen. Pakistan's batting performance was poor, with only captain Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq passing 50 in the first two Tests. Their total of 234 in the first innings was a result of their broken spirit, according to former England batsman Geoffrey Boycott. The series is expected to be tight, with Pakistan needing to improve their confidence and shot selection. The third Test is set to begin on 3 August at Edgbaston.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is initiating a review to assess the quality of life and care for older people in residential care. She plans to gather evidence from pensioners, their families, and care providers through personal meetings and correspondence. The review will focus on factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Rochira aims to highlight both positive and negative experiences to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The goal is to ensure that those responsible for these services understand the realities of residential care and take necessary actions to improve the quality of life for older residents. However, Mario Kreft, the chair of Care Forum Wales, expressed disappointment that the review panel lacks representation from individuals with direct experience in care homes, which he believes could hinder effective partnership and engagement with the sector.

Paul Sheerin, a 39-year-old former Aberdeen midfielder, has been appointed as the new manager of Aberdeen FC, replacing Neil Cooper. Sheerin has been player-manager at Arbroath since 2010, where he led the team to win the Scottish Third Division title and secure promotion in 2011, their first national trophy. Arbroath were relegated to Scottish League Two after finishing bottom of League One in the 2013-14 season. Aberdeen's chief executive, Duncan Fraser, stated that Sheerin was chosen after a thorough process by head coach Derek McInnes. Despite Arbroath's chairman, John Christison, wishing to retain Sheerin's services, he expressed understanding and support for Sheerin's desire to return to Aberdeen. Sheerin has a history of playing for several Scottish clubs and Östersunds in Sweden, and he also earned a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s.

Swansea City will be managed by assistant manager Paul Williams and coach Kevin Curtis for their upcoming match against Bournemouth, following the sacking of Bob Bradley. The club aims to appoint a new manager promptly, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement being their top choice. Curtis, a former player who witnessed Swansea's rise through the divisions, believes the team has lost its identity and direction since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014. He emphasizes the importance of staying in the Premier League, noting the difficulty of rebounding from relegation due to the strengthened Championship. Curtis is confident in the current squad's ability to avoid relegation and reminds new signings of the club's history and the significance of maintaining their Premier League status for the club and the local community.

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, revolutionized the human genome mapping process, turning it into a competitive race. Despite his controversial methods and wealth, his efforts significantly accelerated the process. After the human genome publication, Venter embarked on creating a synthetic life form, resulting in Synthia, which was detailed in the journal Science. Born in 1946, Venter initially pursued surfing and avoided academic excellence. His time in Vietnam as a naval orderly inspired his medical career and instilled a sense of urgency in his work.

Venter excelled in research during his medical training and, by the 1980s, was working at the National Institute of Health. He introduced automation to speed up gene decoding, focusing on messenger RNA instead of the entire genome. His rapid gene sequencing success, however, drew criticism, particularly from James Watson, leading Venter to establish The Institute for Genomic Research in 1992.

In 1995, Venter announced the first complete genome of Haemophilus influenzae, and in 1998, he founded Celera Genomics to decode the human genetic code in three years, challenging the public project's 10-year timeline. Both efforts published their results in 2001, with Venter's approach sparking controversy due to its disregard for scientific conventions like open data access.

Venter's financial success allowed him to fund his scientific endeavors independently. In 2006, he established the J Craig Venter Institute to create synthetic life forms. Simultaneously, he led the Sorcerer II expedition, collecting marine life for genetic research to understand gene evolution and function. The synthetic life breakthrough, while controversial, was seen by Venter as a potential catalyst for a new industrial revolution, with synthetic microbes potentially helping reduce oil dependency and mitigate environmental damage.

The Sutton Trust warns that many apprenticeships in England are of low quality and too short, unlike Germany's highly respected vocational education system. The study, conducted by the Boston Consulting Group, indicates that fewer than 200,000 of the 520,000 apprenticeships in England annually are rated at level three, equivalent to A-levels. In contrast, Germany offers over half of its employers (51%) the opportunity to participate in apprenticeships, with 570,000 new apprenticeships for young people, most of which are at A-level equivalency.

The report highlights that England's vocational system has 18,000 different qualifications, compared to Germany's 330. Since 2010, more than half (58%) of apprenticeships in England have been below level three, and 75% have been for those over 25, many of whom are already employed. The report also notes that 11 young people compete for each apprenticeship.

Sir Peter Lampl, chairman of the Sutton Trust, criticizes the current system, stating it offers poor opportunities for young people who do not attend university. He calls for a radical expansion of apprenticeships, with up to 300,000 new starts each year, prioritizing level three apprenticeships lasting at least three years, with some four-year courses at level four. No more than 10% of apprenticeships should be two-year courses at level two.

The Association of Colleges acknowledges the need for more level three apprenticeships but also emphasizes the importance of preserving well-respected level two apprenticeships, such as those in construction. They also stress the need for high-quality facilities, expert teaching staff, and improved career guidance.

The Department for Education responds by stating that they are already reforming apprenticeships to increase standards, with over a million people becoming apprentices since 2010. They plan to publish further reforms to enhance apprentices

British Paralympian Sarah Storey, aged 37, won a cycling event in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing more than two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska. This victory marks her 22nd medal in Paralympic history, making her Britain's most decorated female Paralympian. She has won 11 gold, 8 silver, and 3 bronze medals across six Paralympics in both cycling and swimming. Storey, who began her career in swimming at the 1992 Paralympics, has now secured 21 world titles in total. She is aiming for further success at the 2016 Rio de Janeiro Paralympics, including a potential 17th title in the upcoming road race on Saturday.

Hereford United has been expelled from the Football Conference due to unpaid debts, primarily to football creditors, including former manager Martin Foyle, current squad members, and clubs from which they loaned players. The club's financial troubles began after their relegation from the Football League in 2012, worsened by low attendance and unpaid wages. Despite fundraising efforts by fans and an offer from the Hereford United Supporters' Trust to buy the club for £1 and clear the debts, the club failed to meet multiple extended deadlines to pay their football creditors. The last team expelled from the Conference was Chester City in 2010, who later reformed as Chester FC. Hereford's expulsion leaves Chester City in their place, following a dramatic final day of the season where Hereford narrowly avoided relegation. The club's new owner, Tommy Agombar, took over last week but was unable to resolve the financial issues in time.

James Milner, a former Manchester City player, is a 30-year-old English footballer who has earned 61 caps for the senior England team since his debut in 2009. He was part of the England squad for two World Cups and two European Championships, but only played for three minutes during Euro 2016. Milner also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player, with 46 appearances since 2004. He scored his only international goal in England's 5-0 victory over Moldova during the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers. Milner expressed support for Sam Allardyce and the team, wishing them success in the future.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and influential figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge following a prolonged illness. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service planned for a later date. Hogwood founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and led it for three decades, during which the academy produced over 200 CDs, including the first-ever complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. His notable recordings include the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson, recognized as one of the top 20 recordings of all time.

Hogwood studied keyboard at Cambridge University and began his career as a keyboard player and musicologist with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields. He was also a founding member of the Early Music Consort of London. He served as the artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, and was a tutor at Harvard University, honorary professor of music at the University of Cambridge, and a professor-at-large at Cornell University.

His colleagues remembered Hogwood for his generosity, his role as a great ambassador for historically informed music, and his significant impact on the music industry, having nurtured many leading orchestra musicians. He was described as a natural academic, incredibly clever, and a very genial person.

A family from Northern Ireland, whose identity is being protected, is struggling to secure a place for their son in a special school. The boy, who has special needs, was removed from mainstream education in June due to his inability to cope. Despite requesting a place at a special school, they were informed in September that all such schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were full, with no estimated time for availability. The boy's mother expressed his distress over isolation and his confusion about why his siblings can attend school while he cannot. Recently, the family was informed that an additional classroom assistant has been hired at a local special school, potentially allowing their son to start there soon. However, the mother is concerned about the broader implications for other families, as the special needs school system is oversubscribed. The Education Authority, while unable to comment on individual cases due to privacy concerns, is reviewing the need for special school places in Northern Ireland to ensure availability from 2016.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is attempting a takeover of Newport Gwent Dragons, who currently have a lease to use Rodney Parade until 2023. The WRU views the venue as a rugby ground and plans to install an artificial surface, which is against Football League rules. Newport County, currently two points clear of League Two relegation, are protected under their current agreements, as stated by Newport RFC chairman Will Godfrey. The takeover bid will be voted on by Newport Rugby shareholders on May 9. Newport County's relegation to the National League would be a significant blow, according to the club's chief executive, Neil Foxall.

The passage recounts the harrowing experiences of a Sierra Leonean man who was kidnapped by the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels at age 15 during the country's civil war (1991-2002). He was trained as a child soldier, witnessing and participating in atrocities, including drug-induced killings and cannibalism. After escaping to Freetown, he lived a life of crime until meeting Richard Cole, a preacher who founded the Lifeline Nehemiah project. This project provided him with hope, education, and a home, inspiring him to contribute to rebuilding the nation.

When the Ebola virus outbreak hit Sierra Leone in 2014, he and his community viewed it as a common enemy. They established a clinic to treat suspected cases, focusing on education, food distribution, and setting up an Ebola treatment unit. They educated over 10,000 people in local languages, supported 11,000 with food and supplies, and collaborated with other agencies to establish the treatment unit. Despite initial fear and resistance, their efforts saved many lives.

The man now views his life as transformed, regretting his past actions but confident in the future. He emphasizes the importance of investing in young people to change the world, not just Sierra Leone, but globally. The passage concludes with statistics on the Ebola outbreak, noting that Sierra Leone had 3,955 probable, confirmed, and suspected deaths.

A public fundraising campaign successfully raised the necessary funds to prevent the auction of approximately 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs from the Wedgwood Museum. The collection, which was at risk of being sold to pay off the pottery firm's pension debt, will remain on display at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire. The Art Fund led the campaign, and the collection will be gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum before being loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. The collection's preservation was crucial as it represents a significant part of Britain's cultural development and national identity. The Wedgwood Museum inherited the pension bill from Waterford Wedgwood plc, which collapsed in 2009. The museum itself went into administration in 2010, and a high court judge ruled in 2011 that its collection could be sold to reimburse the Pension Protection Fund. Alison Wedgwood, a descendant of Josiah Wedgwood, emphasized the collection's importance to Staffordshire, noting that it could have been "sold and scattered around the globe" without the fundraising efforts. Tristram Hunt MP praised the outcome, highlighting the collection's role in defining Britain's cultural heritage.

Billericay Town Football Club is currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points away from a play-off spot. The club has recently been taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is willing to invest £10,000 weekly. A potential deal is being negotiated whereby Joe Wright, a former contestant of I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here, would acquire a 20% stake in the club and become a director. Wright has a history of playing non-league football for various clubs such as Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. The club also recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky, 35, in March. The specifics of the deal with Wright are still being finalized.

In a match between Blackpool and Colchester United, Blackpool took the lead in the 12th minute when Nathan Delfouneso's chip was turned into the goal by Jamille Matt. Colchester equalized in the 24th minute through Kurtis Guthrie, who scored from a goalmouth scramble following a corner. Despite several close calls, neither team managed to take the lead before halftime. Blackpool missed a golden opportunity to win the game in the 75th minute when Tom Aldred headed wide from close range. The match ended with Colchester playing with 10 men after Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle in injury time. The final score was 1-1.

The Fawley power station, located on the western side of Southampton Water, was commissioned in 1971 and operated for over 40 years before closing in 2013. The 2,000 megawatt oil-fired power station, fueled by a nearby Esso refinery, could power one million homes. The site's 198-meter-high chimney, a prominent feature on the Solent skyline, is set to become the tallest attraction south of London's Shard following a proposed development. Fawley Waterside, the developers, plan to transform the 300-acre site into a £1bn "merchant city" project, featuring a petal-shaped glass structure, a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The chimney will serve as the centerpiece of this development, with construction potentially starting in 2018, pending outline planning permission. Aldred Drummond of Fawley Waterside emphasized the chimney's significance, comparing its potential to the i360 in Brighton or the Spinnaker Tower in Portsmouth, but with the advantage of an already existing structure.

At the Hong Kong championships, 23-year-old British cyclist Jack Latham won a bronze medal in the men's omnium event, following Elinor Barker's silver in the women's scratch race. Latham strategically positioned himself behind Irish rider Felix English, conserving energy before making a powerful final sprint to secure the bronze. Britain's men's team pursuit team, however, lost the bronze to Italy. In the men's keirin, Joe Truman was eliminated in the semi-finals. The women's team pursuit squad, consisting of Emily Nelson, Manon Lloyd, and Ellie Dickinson, along with Olympic gold medallist Elinor Barker, finished 5th in the heats. Olympic gold medallists Chris Boardman and Sir Chris Hoy praised Latham's strategic riding and final sprint. Katy Marchant, the 2016 Olympic bronze medallist in the women's sprint, was eliminated in the first round. She remains focused on her upcoming events and the lead-up to the Tokyo Olympics.

Ross Kemp, who previously portrayed Grant Mitchell in EastEnders from 1990-1999 and again in 2005-2006, is set to make a brief return to the show. This return is to coincide with the final episodes of Dame Barbara Windsor's character, Peggy Mitchell, who was revealed to have cancer returning after her surprise reappearance in Albert Square. Peggy, Phil Mitchell's mother, will die from the disease in emotional scenes scheduled for the spring. Kemp's return aims to reunite the Mitchell brothers with their mother for the last time. EastEnders executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins anticipates this as an opportunity to showcase Kemp and Steve McFadden, who plays Phil, at their best. Grant Mitchell, one of EastEnders' most memorable characters, has been involved in numerous family dramas, including an affair with his brother's wife and his brother marrying his ex-wife.

Sadio Mane scored twice in quick succession as Liverpool defeated Tottenham Hotspur at Anfield. Spurs, who are currently second in the Premier League, struggled with their performance, particularly in the first half. Manager Pochettino acknowledged the team's lack of desire and inability to cope with pressure, which he believes could hinder their Premier League challenge. Spurs have only won twice away from home since September, including losses against Chelsea and Manchester United, and draws against Arsenal and Manchester City. Former Spurs midfielder Danny Murphy criticized the team's defensive performance, noting their lack of pace and a different mindset when playing away from home. If Chelsea win their next match, they could extend their lead to 12 points, a situation Pochettino considers a significant problem for Spurs' title aspirations.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured a significant victory in Nigeria's recent gubernatorial elections, winning 19 out of 28 governor posts. This marks the PDP's most substantial defeat since the end of military rule in 1999, following their loss in the presidential election last month. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari, who defeated President Goodluck Jonathan, is set to be inaugurated on May 29.

The PDP's decline was evident in key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, as well as in Adamawa, a state severely affected by Boko Haram's insurgency. However, the PDP managed to retain control of Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The PDP won eight governorships, primarily in the south-east, with Taraba's result still pending and Imo's election declared inconclusive due to spoilt ballot papers.

The APC's victory has relegated the PDP to a regional party, with strongholds only in the south-east and the oil-rich Niger Delta. Despite this, the APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, a concern for President-elect Buhari due to potential disruptions in oil production by militant groups.

The elections, while marred by violence in some areas, were generally more peaceful than previous elections, indicating a maturing democracy in Nigeria. The PDP will need to undergo introspection and rebuild under new leadership, as voters sought change after 16 years of PDP rule, which was marred by allegations of corruption and perceived failure to address the insurgency in the north-east.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt), taking place in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis from July 19-22, is introducing an augmented reality app. This app will enable visitors to access online content, such as videos and band interviews, by scanning items like signs and posters on the festival site using their phones or tablets. Notable acts performing this year include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. Festival director Caroline Maclennan highlighted that this feature aims to enhance the visitor experience and allow global interaction with the festival, providing a taste of its atmosphere remotely. The app will be updated with new content throughout the event, including interviews and the ability to purchase tickets.

Birmingham's Park View and Nansen Primary schools, rated inadequate by Ofsted, will have their funding agreements terminated. The Park View Educational Trust may be removed from running these schools. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, also rated inadequate, have been warned of potential funding loss unless issues are addressed. A head teacher at one of these schools reported parental attempts to undermine her authority during an Ofsted inspection.

Ofsted published 21 reports on schools allegedly targeted in a hardline Muslim takeover, with five, including Park View and Oldknow, rated inadequate. The reports highlighted issues such as inadequate student safety measures, unvetted external speakers with extremist views, and segregation of boys and girls.

Education Minister Lord Nash criticized the Park View Trust for failing to promote the spiritual, moral, social, and cultural development of pupils and for not eliminating discrimination or fostering good relations. Similar criticisms were leveled at Nansen Primary. Both trusts have been invited to respond before July 4.

Oldknow Academy Trust was ordered to address issues like ending unfavorable treatment of non-Muslims, ceasing gender segregation, and ensuring a balanced curriculum. Golden Hillock School received a similar set of demands.

Parents at these schools have criticized Ofsted's reports, accusing inspectors of bias and loaded questions. They have invited Education Secretary Michael Gove to the schools for an open meeting to discuss the evidence supporting the findings.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The prosecution at Ipswich Crown Court alleges that eye specialist Honey Rose, 35, committed gross negligence manslaughter by failing to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs during the test and refer him for further investigation. This failure led to a build-up of fluid in his brain, increasing pressure in his skull and ultimately causing his death. The prosecution claims Vinnie's death was preventable and would have been avoided if Rose had performed her duties competently. The severity of her actions, according to the prosecution, fell so far below the expected standards that it was criminal. Rose denies the charge, and the trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg, a 42-year-old man from Guthrie, near Forfar, was found guilty of coercing a woman into sexual activity with a man he arranged meetings with, which he filmed. The offenses occurred between September 10, 2013, and September 17, 2014. Weatherhogg was also convicted of sending a sexually explicit video to the victim's sister on Christmas Day, 2014, and of threatening or abusive behavior towards the victim's family. He was placed on the sex offenders register and was deemed a moderate risk of sexual re-offending. The case was remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing due to its severity. Weatherhogg had denied the charges but was found guilty following a trial at Dundee Sheriff Court. The judge, Lady Wolffe, emphasized the need for a sentence reflecting society's strong disapproval of such conduct.

In a T20 match in Greater Noida, Ireland scored 165-5, with Stuart Thompson contributing 56 runs, Gary Wilson adding 41 not out, and captain William Porterfield scoring 39. Afghanistan chased the total comfortably, reaching 171-4 with two overs to spare, thanks to Samiullah Shenwari's 56 and Mohammad Shahzad's 47. The teams will meet again for the second T20 at the same venue on Friday. Ireland's performance was marred by the early dismissal of Paul Stirling for a duck, and despite Thompson and Porterfield's efforts, they fell short of their target score. Afghan batsmen Shahzad and Najeeb Tarakai (27) set the tone with a 51-run opening stand. Afghan spinner Amir Hamza was the most successful bowler, taking 2-23. Ireland's captain, Porterfield, acknowledged their fall short of the desired total and expressed dissatisfaction with their bowling performance. The loss of Boyd Rankin, due to a back problem, added to Ireland's woes, though he is expected to return for the subsequent five ODIs starting on 15 March.

Barcelona, the Spanish champions, have made an additional tax payment of £10.68 million (13,550,830.56 euros) regarding the transfer of Neymar from Santos. The club insists they have not committed any offense, stating the payment is to cover potential interpretations of the contracts involved in the transfer. The total cost of Neymar to Barcelona, including fees, wages, and agents' fees, amounts to £106.8 million. This move comes after former Barcelona president Sandro Rosell resigned amid accusations of misappropriating funds related to the transfer. Rosell is under investigation but denies any wrongdoing. A Spanish judge has ruled there is enough evidence to continue the investigation into the transfer. Barcelona maintains that their original tax payment was in line with their fiscal obligations, but the additional payment was made to protect the club's reputation. Neymar, who has scored 10 goals in 25 appearances for Barcelona this season, has not yet commented on the situation.

The bodies of David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were found on a beach in Koh Tao, Thailand on September 15. Two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, both aged 21, have been arrested and charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery. They are alleged to have confessed to the killings, though there have been reports suggesting they may have withdrawn these confessions. The UK Metropolitan Police sent a team to assist in the investigation, which has now concluded. The team will compile a report and update the families of the victims. Post-mortem examinations revealed that Miller died from drowning and a blow to the head, while Witheridge died from head wounds. DNA found on Witheridge matched samples from the suspects. The UK Foreign Office has expressed concerns about the investigation, particularly regarding the verification of DNA samples and allegations of mistreatment of the suspects. If found guilty, the suspects could face the death penalty.

Scotland's women's national football team, led by forward Kim Little, is on the brink of securing a spot in the 2017 World Cup after winning all five qualifiers. They host Iceland, currently unbeaten and ranked 20th in the world, at Falkirk Stadium. A win would significantly increase their chances of topping the group and avoiding play-offs, which have previously resulted in heartbreak for the team. The match's outcome, along with the return game in Reykjavik, will likely determine the group's top team. Scotland's squad includes 12 players from top European and American leagues, contributing to the team's growth and competitiveness. Kim Little, who recently won the women's Bundesliga with Bayern Munich, emphasizes the benefits of playing in high-level leagues, citing the intense competition and quality training as key factors in improving the national team's performance.

The passage discusses a security vulnerability in Apple's iCloud service that led to the theft of intimate photos of celebrities. This was achieved using third-party software, specifically Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker, which could bypass Apple's existing two-step verification system when accessing iCloud backups. Apple has since implemented an additional security measure, requiring users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device or via Apple's Find My iPhone app after entering their username and password on a new device. This change prevents unauthorized access to iCloud and blocks purchases on iTunes, iBooks, or the App Store.

However, this security feature remains an opt-in choice, and experts suggest it should be the default setting. The new system also sends an email notification when a backup starts downloading. Elcomsoft's owner acknowledged that his software can no longer exploit the vulnerability. Despite this, concerns remain about the recovery key's usability and potential theft. Security expert Prof Alan Woodward from the University of Surrey advocates for two-factor authentication to be the default setting across all tech companies, not just Apple. Apple has stated it plans to more aggressively encourage users to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords. CEO Tim Cook emphasized the company's responsibility to increase user awareness about security measures.

During the 2014 European election campaign, UKIP spent the most at £2,956,737, followed by the Conservatives at £2,980,815, Labour at £1,027,339, and the Liberal Democrats at £1,580,575. UKIP secured the highest number of votes, 4,376,635, spending approximately 68p per vote. Labour, despite coming second, spent the least per vote at 26p. The Liberal Democrats, who lost 11 of their 12 MEPs, spent the most per vote at £1.45. The Green Party, which came fourth, spent £534,249, equating to 43p per vote for their 1,255,573 votes. The six highest-spending parties collectively spent £9,347,087, with all except Labour spending more than in the 2009 European election campaign.

Centre-back Anderson, a 27-year-old former player of Aldershot, Exeter, and Italian clubs, has terminated his contract with Barrow by mutual consent to join another National League team. He might play against his former club on 28 February. Additionally, Torquay United (Gulls) have signed 21-year-old striker Keating, recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams. Keating has experience with Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, pending international clearance. Torquay's manager, Kevin Nicholson, described Anderson as a leader with the right stature and voice, despite his limited game experience for his age. Keating, on the other hand, is described as young, raw, but highly motivated. Torquay currently sits four points above the relegation zone, having won only one of their last six matches.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died shortly after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. He narrowly beat Thistlecrack in a closely contested race. The British Horseracing Authority (BHA) confirmed that Many Clouds suffered from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, a rare occurrence that can happen in horses with no underlying health issues across all disciplines of sport horses. Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, overheating, and wobbling on his feet, but he had never collapsed before and showed no such symptoms after this race. He had previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. Trainer Oliver Sherwood described him as the "horse of a lifetime". Despite his history of overheating, the BHA's acting chief veterinary officer, Tony Welsh, stated that Many Clouds had no significant underlying health issues and his death was due to a rare haemorrhage. The BHA is committed to further understanding the causes of such incidents and exploring preventive measures.

Tricia Marwick, the presiding officer, was visibly emotional as she bid farewell to veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond, who are both standing down as MSPs ahead of the election on 5 May. Salmond, who served as First Minister from 2007 to 2014, used his valedictory address to reiterate his belief that Scotland is "not divided, but diverse," emphasizing the country's journey towards greater parliamentary responsibility. He welcomed the transfer of powers under the Scotland Bill but criticized it for not fulfilling unionist pledges from the referendum campaign. Salmond also joked about the timing of his speech, competing with the UK budget and Cheltenham racecourse.

Duncan McNeil, in his final speech, warned Holyrood to learn from Westminster's committee system, emphasizing the need for accountability and scrutiny. He expressed sadness that Holyrood must now learn from Westminster, a role previously intended for Westminster to learn from Holyrood. Annabel Goldie, another outgoing MSP, humorously mentioned her dealings with Finance Secretary John Swinney, particularly his "huge outbursts of faux indignation." All three MSPs have served Scotland with distinction, according to Marwick.

Emma Watson, known for her role as Hermione Granger in the Harry Potter series, has been cast as Belle in Disney's live-action adaptation of "Beauty and the Beast". Kevin Kline will play Maurice, Belle's father, while Dan Stevens, famous for his role in "Downton Abbey", will portray the Beast. Luke Evans will play the villainous Gaston, and Josh Gad, known for his voice role as Olaf in "Frozen", will play Gaston's sidekick LeFou. Emma Thompson will play Mrs. Potts, the teapot, and Ewan McGregor will voice Lumiere, the candelabra. The film, directed by Bill Condon, is set for release on March 17, 2017, and will begin filming at Shepperton Studios in May.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) is set to announce its decisions regarding potential charges in relation to the 1989 Hillsborough stadium disaster, which resulted in the deaths of 96 football fans. The new inquests last year concluded that the fans were unlawfully killed. The CPS is reviewing evidence against 23 suspects, 15 of whom are linked to the investigation of the disaster's causes, and the remaining eight are related to an inquiry into the conduct of South Yorkshire Police and West Midlands Police following the incident. The families of the victims will be informed of the CPS's decisions at a private meeting in Warrington. Margaret Aspinall, whose 18-year-old son died in the disaster, expressed hope that this marks the end of their long journey for justice, emphasizing their desire for accountability rather than retribution. The families are prepared for a range of emotions as they await the CPS's decisions.

Chelmsford Prison has reported multiple incidents of packages being thrown over its walls, containing contraband items such as mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. A former inmate described the prison as notorious for these issues, stating it is often "flooded" with such items. The Ministry of Justice acknowledged the problem, emphasizing that staff work hard to prevent contraband entry, but more needs to be done. They are exploring additional measures to equip prisons with better tools to combat this issue. A nearby resident reported witnessing these incidents four times in two weeks, expressing concern but not fear. The former inmate also claimed drones were used to deliver contraband, though the Ministry of Justice denied this, stating there's no evidence of drone usage at Chelmsford. New laws have been introduced, imposing up to two years' imprisonment for those caught smuggling packages into prisons.

Brian Wright, 55, from Kempston, is on trial at Luton Crown Court for allegedly causing serious injury to Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, by dangerous driving. The incident occurred last December outside Bedford Road Lower School, where Blackburn was on duty. Wright claims he was blinded by the setting sun and did not see the red traffic light, causing him to collide with Blackburn as she was guiding a woman and her six-year-old daughter across the road. Blackburn suffered serious head injuries and is now receiving residential care. Wright, who has admitted to striking Blackburn, denies the charge and expressed deep remorse, stating he has been haunted by the incident. The court heard that the sun was 10 minutes from setting and could have been directly in Wright's eyes. The trial is ongoing.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner, has announced she will not be participating in the upcoming Commonwealth Games due to her veterinary medicine studies. Her exams are scheduled for May, clashing with the April Games on Australia's Gold Coast. Muir expressed her disappointment, stating that the Commonwealth Games are one of the few opportunities to represent Scotland. Despite this, she emphasized the importance of her degree. Muir recently competed in the World Athletics Championships, finishing 4th in the 1500m and 6th in the 5000m. Her time in the 5000m race was a new personal best of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds. She remains optimistic about her future, suggesting she could compete in at least two more Olympics. Muir also mentioned the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target, despite her busy study schedule.

Trevor Deely, a 22-year-old from County Kildare, disappeared on his way home from a Christmas party in December 2000. A search is currently underway in a three-acre woodland area beside the R112 and River Liffey in Chapelizod, Dublin. The search, expected to last several weeks, involves excavations. Earlier this year, six detectives began a comprehensive review of Deely's disappearance. Enhanced CCTV footage shows Deely talking to a man dressed in black outside the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street, where he worked. The man is believed to have been following Deely, who was returning for an umbrella. The man in black has not been identified, and authorities have renewed their appeal for him to come forward.

Juan Martin del Potro, ranked 165th after a two-year absence due to injuries, defeated Switzerland's Stanislas Wawrinka 3-6, 6-3, 7-6 (7-2), 6-3 in the second round of a Grand Slam tournament. Del Potro, a former world number four and 2009 US Open champion, is playing in his first Grand Slam since the 2014 Australian Open after undergoing three wrist operations. He will next face either France's Lucas Pouille or American Donald Young. Del Potro expressed his joy at returning to competitive tennis and praised the supportive crowd.

In other matches, Australia's Nick Kyrgios, also in the same half of the draw as Andy Murray, overcame a two-set deficit to defeat Germany's Dustin Brown 6-7 (3-7), 6-1, 2-6, 6-4, 6-4. Kyrgios will next play Spain's Feliciano Lopez, who rallied from two sets down to beat Italy's Fabio Fognini 3-6, 6-7 (3-7), 6-3, 6-3, 6-3. Other notable winners included 10th seed Tomas Berdych and 12th seed Jo-Wilfried Tsonga, who both secured straightforward victories over Benjamin Becker and Juan Monaco, respectively.

Tunisia and Morocco faced significant challenges leading up to the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations. Tunisia was initially at risk of being disqualified from the 2017 tournament due to complaints lodged against the Confederation of African Football (Caf) following a controversial quarter-final match against Equatorial Guinea in the 2015 tournament. The Tunisian Football Federation (FTF) criticized the referee's decision to award a penalty in the 90th minute, which led to their loss. However, the FTF clarified that they never accused Caf or the referee of corruption, but rather questioned the suitability of the referee for the match. After a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou in Senegal, Tunisia managed to resolve their differences and secure their participation in the 2017 tournament.

Morocco, on the other hand, was banned from the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw due to their refusal to host the 2015 tournament, citing Ebola fears. The Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) later overturned this ban and reduced a fine imposed on Morocco's FA from $1m to $50,000. Moroccan FA chief Fouzi Lekjaa expressed optimism about the future of African football and Morocco's participation in the sport.

Both Tunisia and Morocco have been assigned to specific groups for the 2017 tournament: Tunisia in Group A with Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti, and Morocco in Group F with Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome. If Tunisia qualifies for the finals, they will be aiming for their thirteenth consecutive appearance, which would set a record.

McLaren, a historically successful Formula 1 team with 182 race wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently experiencing a significant slump. The team's decline began in 2013 due to issues with chassis design, despite having a superior engine. The current challenges lie with the Honda power-unit, a stark contrast to their past success with Honda engines, including a dominant 1988 season where Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost won 15 out of 16 races.

McLaren's last constructors' title was in 1998, and they were unjustly stripped of the 2007 title due to a scandal involving illegal Ferrari technical information. The team has also faced other controversies, such as 'lie-gate' in 2009. Despite periods of success, including victories with Mika Hakkinen and Lewis Hamilton, the team has not won a race since 2012.

The team's current predicament is part of a cyclical pattern of triumph and decline. Ron Dennis, who has been instrumental in building and rebuilding the team, remains optimistic about McLaren's future. He believes the team will break Mercedes' dominance and win championships again, with Fernando Alonso's return in 2015 seen as a testament to this belief. Alonso joined McLaren for what he perceived as the best chance to secure his third world title.

Currently, McLaren's progress is largely based on belief, as they strive to regain their former glory and fulfill the expectations tied to one of F1's most prestigious names.

On 6 October 2014, paramedics were dispatched to Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST following a sudden death. Police arrived shortly after, discovering patrons still present and till receipts indicating alcohol was served until 04:49 BST. The court ordered the bar's closure for three months. Colleen O'Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, both from Kevin Lynch Park, were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. O'Neill faced two counts, while Thomas faced one. The defense solicitor stated that licensing laws in Dungiven were not strictly followed, and the premises were operating beyond legal hours. The judge, noting O'Neill's "appalling record," expressed concern over his inability to impose a custodial sentence. O'Neill was fined £3,000, and Thomas was fined £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for the most 3-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. Curry, who entered the game four 3-pointers shy of his previous record of 272, hit six before halftime and eight overall, aiding his team's comeback from a 13-point deficit. Klay Thompson contributed 26 points, and Curry added nine assists. Lamarcus Aldridge scored 27 points and Damian Lillard added 20 for the Blazers, who have secured the Northwest Division. Elsewhere, Pau Gasol had 16 points and 15 rebounds, and the Chicago Bulls overcame a 19-point halftime deficit to defeat the Miami Heat 89-78. The Bulls, led by Gasol and Derrick Rose (12 points), went on a 39-8 run after halftime, while the Heat were outscored 57-27 in the second half. Dwyane Wade scored nine points, shooting poorly at 4 for 20. Hassan Whiteside had 19 points and 16 rebounds for the Heat.

YouTube star Bas van Velzen surprised Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic at Melwood, Liverpool's training ground. The players were led to believe they were meeting a competition winner for a free-kick masterclass. However, van Velzen, known for his free-kick skills on YouTube, showcased his abilities, impressing the Liverpool quartet. He scored a goal that left the stand-in goalkeeper helpless, and later, Balotelli matched his effort. Van Velzen also revealed Balotelli's famous slogan, which the Italian wore during Manchester City's 6-1 win over Manchester United in 2011. Van Velzen expressed his joy at the experience, stating it was every fan's dream to play with their idols.

Angelina Jolie, who carries the BRCA1 gene mutation, serves as an example for women diagnosed with breast cancer caused by the same gene. A Canadian study indicates that removing ovaries, a procedure known as oophorectomy, can significantly reduce the risk of death from breast cancer by more than 60%. The study analyzed 676 breast cancer patients with mutated BRCA1 or BRCA2 genes, with 345 undergoing oophorectomy after diagnosis. The 20-year survival rate for the entire group was 77.4%. For BRCA1 carriers who had their ovaries removed within two years of diagnosis, the death risk was reduced by 73%. The protective effect of oophorectomy against breast cancer was immediate and lasted for 15 years. The study also found a 65% reduction in death from all causes associated with oophorectomy. The results suggest that oophorectomy should be considered as part of the treatment discussion for BRCA mutation carriers with early-stage breast cancer. Women with a significant family history of breast cancer, particularly those who inherit the faulty BRCA1 or BRCA2 genes, have a 50 to 80% lifetime risk of developing breast cancer. Genetic tests are available for women likely to have these mutations. Jolie, who has six children, shared that having her ovaries removed did not diminish her femininity.

On Easter Sunday, a married couple, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were struck and killed by an Amtrak train in Durham, North Carolina, around 9:45 am. The train, number 80, known as the Carolinian, was traveling from Charlotte to New York City. The incident occurred on Norfolk-Southern property. None of the 166 passengers on board were injured, but a man who fell ill during the delay received treatment. The train was delayed for approximately two hours and 45 minutes before resuming its journey. A local man, James Thompson, reported that the couple may have been homeless and lived in a nearby camp. They were known to collect scrap metal and had asked Thompson for help crossing the railroad tracks with their grocery cart. The train's next stop was Raleigh, about 25 miles northwest of Durham, and the usual travel time from Charlotte to New York City is around 13 hours and 30 minutes.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellin Cartel, worked as a DEA undercover operative for 27 years after fleeing Colombia in the 1980s due to a confrontation with his boss. Toro, who was not paid for his work, was promised U.S. citizenship in exchange for providing crucial information about his former bosses and associates. His contributions significantly aided in the prosecution of key figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Despite his invaluable service, Toro is now facing deportation due to declining health forcing his retirement. The DEA has refused to assist him with citizenship, leaving him in a state of fear and uncertainty. Toro's handler, DEA Agent Mike McManus, and a former colleague have provided financial support for his operations, but Toro remains in legal limbo, unable to collect social security benefits or secure a green card or passport. He is prepared to go into hiding if necessary, emphasizing his desire to fulfill the promise made to him years ago.

The U.S. body responsible for internet address regulation, ICANN, is investigating a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., for potentially illegal practices involving the new '.sucks' domain. Vox Populi has been selling domain names like 'youtube.sucks', 'bing.sucks', 'visa.sucks', and 'bankofamerica.sucks' for around $2,499 annually, with most being resold for about $2,000 a year. Celebrities such as Kevin Spacey and Taylor Swift have reportedly paid to have their names removed from these domains. ICANN initially approved the '.sucks' domain but is now reconsidering due to complaints from industry groups like Microsoft, Verizon, and eBay, who label it a'shakedown scheme'. ICANN has sent a letter to the U.S. Federal Trade Commission and Canada's Office of Consumer Affairs to determine if Vox Populi's actions are illegal. If found in breach of contract, ICANN could seek to change Vox Populi's behavior or declare them in violation.

A mother was arrested 27 years after her stillborn baby's body was discovered in a Sainsbury's bag floating in a pond in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk. The case remained unsolved until a DNA sample from the exhumed body matched a relative in the national police database. The woman, who concealed her pregnancy, admitted to delivering the baby stillborn and placing the body in the pond. She was initially arrested on suspicion of infanticide, but the charge was dropped after she explained the circumstances. The baby, named Peter after the church, was reburied in the churchyard on the 26th anniversary of his discovery. The case was solved using advanced DNA techniques, and no foul play was found. A support group, Hana's Gift, provided a new headstone for the baby's grave.

In 2010, Kristopher Hicks, then 23, was a passenger in a taxi driven by Michael Young in Bath, Somerset. Young, a former soldier, mistakenly believed Hicks was planning to "do a runner" and decided to drive him back to the taxi rank to teach him a lesson. When Hicks objected, Young continued driving for nearly a mile, causing Hicks to jump from the moving vehicle. Hicks suffered severe brain injuries, developed epilepsy, and now requires round-the-clock care from his mother. The High Court ruled that Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling him to damages. The exact amount of compensation, expected to be around 50% of the family's request and potentially "hundreds of thousands of pounds," is yet to be determined. The judge acknowledged the incident's severity and the risk Young's actions posed to Hicks' life and limb. Hicks' lawyers stated that he now suffers from post-traumatic epilepsy, headaches, fatigue, social and behavioral problems, and a lack of taste and smell, and is unable to work. Both parties have been granted permission to appeal.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas on Wednesday night due to multiple storms, with reports of twisters. A tornado was spotted about 6 miles northwest of Goddard, near Wichita, but it missed the city, posing risks to other communities. Severe weather expert Chad Myers warned that nighttime tornadoes are particularly dangerous. Additional tornado sightings were reported in southwestern Kansas, near Aetna. Missouri was also affected, with a potential tornado touchdown in Potosi, about 70 miles from St. Louis. Potosi experienced wind damage, flooding, and hail as large as baseballs. More storms are forecast for the midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

Luke Rockhold is preparing to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight fight in New Jersey, aiming for his fourth consecutive victory and a title shot. Rockhold plans to dominate by being aggressive and cutting off Machida's evasive movements, forcing him to engage in Rockhold's preferred style of fighting. Rockhold believes Machida has limited options on the feet and virtually none on the ground. He respects Machida's martial arts skills but is confident in his own abilities, including his speed and hip movement. Both fighters are coming off recent victories, with Machida also targeting a title shot if he wins. Machida acknowledges some weaknesses in Rockhold but emphasizes the need to feel the fight and capitalize on any mistakes. He is well-prepared, having trained for eight weeks with Glover Teixeira and other fighters.

In Fort Pierce, Florida, a light general aviation aircraft, an Aerostar, performed a gear-up landing at the Aero Acre residential airpark. The plane touched down without its landing gear deployed, causing it to skid along the runway on its belly, damaging its propellers. The video maker, who witnessed the incident, noted the distinctive sound of the propellers hitting the ground and the wings bouncing. Upon realizing his mistake, the 85-year-old pilot, Chris Georgaklis, re-engaged the engines and managed to take off, flying 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale where he landed safely. Georgaklis, an experienced pilot with nearly 50 years of flying, was accompanied by his dog, Buddy. The incident is under investigation by the FAA, with human error being the most common cause of gear-up landings.

Manuel Pellegrini, Manchester City's manager, has expressed disappointment in Yaya Toure's underperformance this season but has pledged to support the Ivorian midfielder until the end of the campaign. Despite City's faltering Premier League defense and the club's willingness to listen to offers for Toure in the summer, the 31-year-old is determined not to be forced out. Pellegrini dismissed claims that Toure needs a rest, emphasizing his importance to the team. City's goalkeeper, Joe Hart, acknowledged the players' responsibility for their poor performances and affirmed Pellegrini's continued backing from the dressing room. Meanwhile, West Ham manager Sam Allardyce warned Aaron Cresswell, a target for Manchester City, about the potential pitfalls of moving to the club, citing the experiences of Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia member known as the "Godfather of Uxbridge," was given a seven-year sentence in 1999 by an Italian court for his role in the Cosa Nostra. He lived in the UK for over 20 years under the name Marc Skinner before being arrested in 2013 on a European Arrest Warrant. In February 2014, he lost his extradition battle, but his case expired in October 2014, as per Italian law which states that a sentence is extinguished once more than double the time of the penalty has passed. Despite this, the Italian Supreme Court still needs to review the case. Rancadore's solicitor, Karen Todner, confirmed that the European Arrest Warrant will be withdrawn, allowing Rancadore to remain in the UK with his family. The extradition process has been criticized for being a waste of time and resources.

Mr. Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls, is one of the three 7-2 co-favorites for the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. The other favorites are Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson's Sprinter Sacre, who will be ridden by Nico de Boinville due to Barry Geraghty's injury. AP McCoy, who will be riding Mr. Mole, will have his last ride in a Grade One race. This race is significant as it was after winning with Mr. Mole at Newbury in February that McCoy announced his retirement. The race will have six other runners, including Mick Channon's Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter, the mother of Marcia Ritter, who was murdered 40 years ago, recently viewed crime scene photos of her daughter's body. Marcia was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. Her body was discovered 33 days after she disappeared, and Ritter's then-husband advised her against seeing the body and the crime scene photos. Ritter, who had declined to see the photos for decades, requested them last year from Mickey Miller, the lead investigator. She viewed them on Miller's laptop, describing the gruesome condition of her daughter's body, including a swollen face, black mouth, vomit, pulled-out hair, and blood on her scalp. Ritter expressed a desire for revenge, stating she would kill Barrett if she had a gun. Barrett, 68, was found guilty of second-degree murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years in prison. The case was Nashville's most notorious unsolved murder for 33 years until Barrett was arrested in 2006 after DNA evidence linked him to the crime. Barrett had been in prison on sex charges between 1974 and 2002, except for a brief period when Marcia disappeared.

Rory McIlroy, the world number one golfer, believes it's "unthinkable" that he won't win the Masters at some point to complete the career grand slam. He views his final-round collapse at Augusta National in 2011 as the most important day of his career, as it taught him valuable lessons. McIlroy aims to become the sixth player to win all four major titles, following in the footsteps of Sarazen, Hogan, Player, Nicklaus, and Woods. Despite having only one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, McIlroy is confident about his chances at Augusta, considering it a course where he can excel. He emphasizes the significance of winning his first green jacket, stating that not achieving this would leave him "very, very disappointed" in his career. McIlroy's resilience was evident after his 2011 collapse, as he went on to win his first major title two months later and added more victories in 2012 and 2014. He hopes to use the golf course as his sanctuary amidst the hype and pressure surrounding the Masters.

This week, several trending stories dominated online discussions. In the New York area, following heavy rainfall, four rainbows were spotted in the early morning sky, captured by Amanda Curtis, CEO of a fashion company. In rural China, a new trend of hiring exotic dancers for funerals is being phased out due to a government crackdown on vice. Robert Downey Jr. became agitated during an interview about his private life. A new beauty trend, lip plumping inspired by Kylie Jenner, emerged, involving sucking on a jar to achieve fuller lips, trending under the hashtag #kyliejennerchallenge. A 102-year-old woman, Alice Barker, was featured in a time-traveling film. A prom-posal involving a bomb reference was rejected by a school, sparking accusations of racism. Ewan McGregor was cast as Lumiere in the live-action 'Beauty and the Beast', generating significant social media interest. The trailer for 'Black Mass' featuring Johnny Depp in an unrecognizable role also made waves. A creative pregnancy announcement referencing 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air' and a military dad photobombing his son in uniform were other notable trends.

The passage reveals alarming figures from the UK's official health and social care information centre, indicating that 272 children were hospitalized in England over the past year due to Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS), a condition caused by alcohol exposure in the womb. However, experts warn that the actual number of affected children could be significantly higher. Research by the World Health Organization suggests that at least one in 100 babies born in the UK may suffer learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to alcohol exposure, equating to about 7,500 cases annually.

The passage also highlights the lifelong impact of FAS, using 15-year-old Niamh Brown as an example. Niamh, who was adopted, was diagnosed with FAS at age five and requires constant assistance due to her condition. Her parents, Julia and Simon, established the Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorder Trust to support others affected by this issue.

Additional medical complications linked to alcohol consumption during pregnancy include liver, kidney, and heart problems, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy. The UK government advises pregnant women not to drink alcohol, with a maximum recommended consumption of up to two units no more than twice a week. However, Elizabeth Mitchell of the National Organization for Fetal Alcohol Syndrome advocates for stricter guidelines, suggesting that pregnant women should abstain from alcohol entirely.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, a 31-year-old ex-juvenile offender known as 'Boomerang Boy' or 'Homing Pigeon Boy' due to his tendency to return home after committing crimes, attempted to rob Shildon Post Office and Stores in County Durham on March 15 at 8 PM. Wielding an axe, McKerry demanded cash from assistant Andrea Brighty, but was unexpectedly tackled by the store owner, Sab Dhillon. Dhillon's wife, Sam, assisted by hitting McKerry with a baseball bat twice, helping to disarm him. The struggle resulted in McKerry's face being revealed to the cameras. McKerry, who has a history of shoplifting, aggravated vehicle-taking, sending indecent letters, and burglary, was arrested by the police shortly after. He pleaded guilty to attempted robbery at Durham Crown Court and was sentenced to six years in prison. McKerry earned his nicknames due to his frequent returns home after crimes, including a notable incident where he stole 22 charity boxes while dressed as a woman.

Four Royal Navy sailors - Joshua Finbow, Craig Stoner, Simon Radford, and Darren Smalley - have been charged with the gang rape of a young woman at a Canadian naval barracks in Nova Scotia. The alleged assault occurred on April 10 after the sailors returned from an ice hockey game. The victim, in her early 20s, had accompanied a friend to a party hosted by local Canadian servicemen. The four accused, who were playing for the Royal Navy ice hockey team in a tournament, appeared in a Dartmouth court and were given bail conditions that include living on the nearby Stadacona naval base in Halifax, surrendering their passports, and continuing to work for the Royal Navy. They are forbidden to contact the victim or six witnesses, leave Nova Scotia, or apply for new passports. The charges, sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, carry a maximum sentence of 14 years in prison. The investigation is ongoing, and forensic tests may result in additional charges. The British High Commission is assisting Canadian authorities with the investigation.

Valerie Jackson, a mother from Las Vegas, is caring for her four-year-old son RJ, who suffers from Netherton's syndrome, an extremely rare skin disease affecting only 70 people worldwide. RJ's skin appears red, scaly, and inflamed, often covered in dry skin that resembles scales. Valerie regularly applies creams to prevent his skin from drying out and cracking. Despite her diligent care, Valerie has faced ignorance and accusations of child abuse from strangers and even had armed police called on her while shopping. RJ's condition has also led to social exclusion, with play centers denying entry and adults making cruel comments. Netherton's syndrome, a more severe form of ichthyosis, causes skin to appear red and scaly, and can lead to infections due to inflammation. There is no cure for the condition, but symptoms can improve over time. Valerie found support through a Facebook group for Netherton's syndrome, where she learned about the condition and connected with other parents. She continues to advocate for her son and educate others about his rare disease.

The controversial "Are You Beach Body Ready?" ad campaign by protein world, featuring a toned model named Renee Somerfield, has been removed from London Underground stations. The campaign sparked significant backlash, with over 50,000 signatures on a Change.org petition and more than 200 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA). Critics argued the ad promoted an unhealthy body image and implied only women who looked like the model were beach-ready. Several posters were also defaced by angry bloggers. Transport for London (TFL) confirmed the posters were being removed as their three-week advertising period ended, but noted they would consider public reaction if a similar request was made in the future. The company defended the campaign, stating it aimed to inspire health and fitness. However, the campaign also drew support from some, including TV presenter Katie Hopkins and writer Samantha Brick, who argued it encouraged personal responsibility for health and fitness. The ASA is currently assessing the complaints against the ad.

Rail firms, including First Great Western (FGW), are facing criticism for planning significant fare hikes, up to 87%, just ten days after the general election. This contradicts pledges by main party leaders, including Prime Minister David Cameron, to freeze prices. Cameron, whose Witney constituency is affected, has requested FGW to urgently review its decision to increase fares between London and the Cotswolds. The current off-peak return fare from Charlbury to London will rise from £33.30 to £62.40 on May 17.
