Other notable hikes include a 24.5% increase in the anytime return between Stafford and Liverpool with Virgin Trains, and a 22% increase in the anytime first-class day return from Manchester to Stoke. Virgin Trains defended its hikes, stating they primarily affect 'virgin trains-only fares' which are at least 20% cheaper than competitors' tickets. The increases have angered passengers, especially given the political promises to freeze fares.

Former soldier John Young, 66, and his newlywed wife Elaine, 54, were attacked in their home in Oldham, Greater Manchester. The couple was sitting in their front room when thugs began pelting their front window with stones. When John went to confront the attackers, a brick was thrown through the door, striking him in the left eye. He suffered an open wound to his forehead and serious injury to his eye, leading to permanent blindness in that eye. The attack occurred just three weeks after their wedding, and the couple, who have no children, are now too scared to return to their home. Police have launched an investigation, suggesting the attack might have been carried out by yobs "messing around," but no motive has been established. Detective Constable Gareth Gwilliam urged anyone with information to come forward.

Tom Poynton, a 25-year-old wicketkeeper for Derbyshire, has signed a one-year contract extension following his successful return from a serious leg injury. Poynton missed the entire 2014 season due to injuries sustained in a road accident that also resulted in the death of his father, Keith. He underwent an ankle operation and made his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour in Abu Dhabi. Derbyshire's Elite Performance Director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's exceptional character and hard work, expressing the club's delight in his return. The new contract is intended to boost Poynton's confidence and allow him to perform well during the upcoming season.

Five-year-old Harley Renshaw, from Stretford, was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer, which had spread to his kidney, lungs, bones, and neck. To cope with his treatment, Harley created a Ninja Turtle-themed mask for his radiotherapy sessions. His bravery and positive attitude gained widespread attention, including a box of Ninja Turtle presents from children's TV channel Nickelodeon. After a year of intensive chemotherapy, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy, Harley has been given the all-clear by doctors. He will continue to undergo regular check-ups to ensure he remains cancer-free. Harley's family is overjoyed, and he has become the face of Cancer Research UK's Kids and Teens campaign, aiming to raise funds for child cancer research. Neuroblastoma is a cancer of specialized nerve cells, affecting fewer than 100 children in the UK annually, and is the second most common solid tumor in childhood. Symptoms vary depending on the tumor's location and can include pain, loss of appetite, and difficulty urinating or swallowing. Treatment options include surgery, chemotherapy, antibody treatment, and radiotherapy.

Tim Sherwood, former Aston Villa manager, advises Jack Grealish to prioritize his club career over his international future. Grealish, a 19-year-old midfielder, has been impressing with his performances for Aston Villa, particularly in their FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool. His skills have caught the attention of both the Republic of Ireland and England, who are vying for his international allegiance. Sherwood believes Grealish should focus on solidifying his position in the Villa first team, emphasizing that his current success is a result of his efforts at the club. Sherwood, drawing from his own experience with Nabil Bentaleb, suggests that Grealish should make his decision based on his personal feelings. Grealish's father, Kevin, echoes this sentiment, urging his son to maintain his club form before considering international opportunities. The young player is expected to make his decision by the end of the season, with a potential friendly appearance for either country.

The passage discusses the significant and often surprising landing fees for private jets at various airports around the world. These fees, which can reach thousands of dollars per landing, provide insight into the most popular transport hubs for the wealthy. Despite the high costs, private jet travel is a growing trend, with 2.5 million private flights recorded in the U.S. in 2013 and 705,000 in Europe. The industry is worth $16.7 trillion in the U.S. and $15.8 trillion in Europe.

The busiest weekends for private jets are during major sporting events, such as the Super Bowl in America and the Monaco Grand Prix. For instance, a round-trip from New York to Glendale for the Super Bowl can cost around $38,000 on a medium jet and $54,000 on a long-range jet.

The passage also lists the landing fees for several airports. Haneda Airport in Tokyo, Japan, is the most expensive, charging £4,559 ($6,850) for a 767-400 jet. Other expensive airports include Narita International Airport in Tokyo (£3,728 or $5,600), Kansai International Airport in Osaka (£3,594 or $5,400), and Bristol Airport in Bristol, England (£2,929 or $4,400). Surprisingly, Salzburg Airport in Austria and Darwin International Airport in Australia also appear in the top 10, charging £2,530 ($3,800) and £3,059 ($4,600) respectively.

The data highlights the high costs associated with private jet travel and the popularity of certain airports among the wealthy.

Katie Gallegos, a dog resort owner from Clackamas County, Oregon, took her dogs, Cooper and Daisy, to a McDonald's drive-thru for ice cream. Cooper, known for his quick eating habits, swiftly consumed the entire ice cream cone in one bite, while Daisy took a few ladylike licks. The video of this event has garnered over seven million views, with mixed reactions from viewers. Some found it cute and hilarious, while others criticized Gallegos for feeding her dogs fast food. Gallegos defended her actions, stating that Cooper is an athletic dog in good health and that he occasionally enjoys an ice cream treat, similar to her previous dog who lived to 19 years old. In contrast, Daisy, due to her smaller size, only gets a few licks. The dogs also have a fondness for Starbucks, where Cooper was seen taking a whole cup of a "pup-uccino" (whipped cream) away to consume. Gallegos clarified that the pup-uccino does not contain coffee.

Gary Locke, the former Heart of Midlothian manager, has been appointed as the permanent manager of Kilmarnock on a three-year contract. He initially joined the club as assistant to Allan Johnston last summer. Following Johnston's resignation in early February, Locke assumed the role of interim manager. During his interim period, Locke has demonstrated success, losing only once in his seven games. He is set to address the press regarding his new role in a conference on Friday morning.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, has accused Seminole County Elementary School of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, due to the essential oils he wears to manage his condition. Kemp applies these oils, manufactured by Doterra, to Logan's head and neck to help him stay calm and focused. She claims that Logan has been using these oils throughout the school year without issue, but a teacher's aide recently complained about the scent being a distraction. Kemp received a letter from the school board stating the oils created a problem for staff and students. Despite the threat of suspension, Kemp insists on continuing to use the oils, citing their positive impact on her son. The Lake County School District later clarified they would not suspend Logan, considering it a health issue. The oils used by the family include scents like lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood.

A beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton, known as the Sandpiper Complex, was completely destroyed by a fire on Wednesday afternoon. The blaze, which started around 3 PM, spread through 90 condos before the building collapsed. The fire was so intense that it melted the paint off nearby buildings and could be seen from three miles away. Twelve fire crews were deployed, but they couldn't get inside the building due to the strength of the flames. The fire is currently under investigation, with claims suggesting it may have started near a car parked by the complex. The Sandpiper Complex is typically used as a holiday home by residents between May and November. Janice Sklarek, an owner, and Rob Taber, the building manager, both lost everything in the fire. Despite the fire's intensity, the wind was offshore, providing good visibility for the firefighters.

The passage describes Queen Elizabeth II, who is approaching her 89th birthday, enjoying a ride on her fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park. Despite her age, she continues to love horses, having started riding at the age of four. The Queen is known for her preference for silk scarves over riding helmets, a choice she attributes to her hair maintenance. She has a long history with horses, with notable mounts including Betsy and Surprise. However, due to a knee injury, she has reduced her riding time in recent years. The Queen breeds several breeds of horses and ponies, including fell ponies, at Hampton Court and Balmoral. Fell ponies, an ancient breed, are known for their docile nature, hardiness, and use in trade and mining. The Queen's ride on Carltonlima Emma is a testament to her enduring passion for horses.

A dispute over noise levels between two neighbors in North Brisbane ended tragically with the death of 55-year-old Leon Yeaman. The altercation occurred around 9 PM on a Thursday night when Yeaman was reportedly making a lot of noise in his yard. Phillip Pama, a 28-year-old shift worker and married father of three, confronted Yeaman, leading to a physical confrontation. Pama allegedly struck Yeaman with a single punch, which proved fatal. Pama's defense lawyer stated that Pama was pushed while throwing the punch and did not see it connect. Yeaman, known for his loud behavior and drinking, was described by neighbors as both generous and a schizophrenic pensioner who enjoyed playing loud music. Pama, who has no prior history of violence, was granted conditional bail with restrictions including surrendering his passport, adhering to a curfew, and regular police reports. The case is set to return to court on May 18.

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old music teacher in Shatura, Russia, was arrested after attempting to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old former student, Damian Vanya. The relationship ended when Vanya left Simonova for a classmate. Simonova offered 100,000 rubles (approximately £1,400) for the hit, detailing her desire for Vanya to suffer unbearable pain, including broken limbs and damaged kidneys, leading to a slow, painful death. The plan was foiled by an undercover police operation, and Simonova was apprehended in her car. She now faces up to 15 years in prison for attempted murder. Vanya, relieved by the outcome, expressed hope that Simonova would receive a severe sentence.

Jose Mourinho, the Chelsea football manager, revealed in an interview with The Daily Telegraph that he maintains a strong faith in God, praying daily but not regularly attending church. He emphasizes that his conversations with God are strictly personal and never about football. Mourinho, known for his intense demeanor on the sidelines, asserts that he is a good person with no issues in his family or friendships. He and his wife, Matilde Faria, have been ambassadors for the World Food Programme, working against hunger. Mourinho strives to separate his professional and personal life, ensuring his family is not involved in his football discussions. Despite his competitive nature, he acknowledges making mistakes but believes a person is more than their professional life. Currently, Chelsea is leading the league, and Mourinho was recently fined for claiming a 'campaign' against Chelsea following a diving incident.

Bob Barker, the former host of "The Price is Right" for 35 years, made a surprise return to the show on April 1, 2022, for the first time in eight years. He hosted the first game, "Lucky Seven," and appeared to be in good health at the age of 91. After the game, he handed over the hosting duties to the current host, Drew Carey, who concluded the show. Despite his long absence, Barker seemed to have retained his hosting skills seamlessly.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. on Friday morning at around 12:30 am for allegedly attempting to break into a house and damaging property. The incident occurred on the 3200 block of D Street SE. Baldwin, who is part of the foreign missions branch attached to the State Department, has been charged with felony attempted burglary and destruction of property. In response to the arrest, the Secret Service revoked his security clearance and placed him on leave. Baldwin was scheduled to be arraigned later that Friday, and no attorney was listed in the court records. This incident follows another case where a high-ranking supervisor was put on leave for alleged misconduct, which is also under police investigation. Both cases are being scrutinized by the Department of Homeland Security's inspector general, adding to the recent string of issues for the agency tasked with protecting the President and his family.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, had a close encounter with a hungry lion at the city's safari park. Saeed, armed only with his camera, crept up to within 10 feet of the lion to capture its image. The clicking sound of his camera's shutter alerted the lion, causing it to aggressively jump towards him. Saeed managed to scramble into his car just in time, narrowly escaping the lion's attack. Despite the danger, Saeed expressed that he was initially thinking of showcasing the lion's character and status through his photographs. Reflecting on the incident, he admitted it was a close call and he wouldn't attempt it again.

New York City police have released images of a distinctive tattoo found on an unidentified woman's leg, hoping to identify her. The woman, estimated to be between 25 and 45 years old, was found unconscious on March 22 in Brooklyn's Gravesend section near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue. Despite paramedics' efforts, she was pronounced dead that evening. The tattoo, believed to be the name 'Monique' etched across a ribbon within a heart topped with a rose, was faded but distinctive. No identification was found on her, and the cause of death is still under investigation by the medical examiner. Anyone with information is urged to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers.

Hannah and Alex, a New Zealand couple who returned from the UK in 2009, built a two-bedroom home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck due to financial constraints. The project, which took about a year and a half, involved welding a steel frame, adding wood, and incorporating various comforts such as a wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and a loft for their cat. The home is primarily solar-powered, with the first power bill amounting to just $25. Water is sourced from a nearby spring. The couple's ingenuity and resourcefulness have resulted in a nearly self-sufficient living space surrounded by nature in Nelson, New Zealand, all for approximately $25,000. They plan to build another similar home in the future.

Researchers from Northwestern University, led by Courtney Blackwell, have found that kindergarten children who shared iPads in class significantly outperformed their peers in early literacy tests. The study, conducted over an academic year in a midwestern suburban school district, involved 352 students. The shared iPad group scored approximately 30 points higher than students who used the device individually and those who did not use iPads at all. The research suggests that the collaborative learning around the technology, rather than collaboration itself, is the key factor contributing to improved literacy skills. Blackwell's findings challenge the skepticism of the National Association of Head Teachers regarding the use of technology as a teaching aid in non-IT classes, implying that schools might need to reconsider how they utilize tablets to maximize their effectiveness, particularly in earlier grades.

A two-legged piglet, born to farmer Ms. Duan in Qionglai City, Sichuan Province, China, has gained internet fame for its ability to walk on its front trotters. Despite being born without back legs, the piglet has learned to balance and forage for food, often appearing to wobble but always regaining its balance. The piglet, nicknamed 'Super Pig', interacts well with its siblings who have all four legs. The heartwarming video of its progress has attracted thousands of viewers and visitors to the farm. This is not the first instance of a two-legged animal gaining popularity in China; a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo also became a star for walking on its front paws.

On Sunday, during the inaugural Indycar Grand Prix of Louisiana, Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured when he was struck by Francesco Drake's car. Drake had come in for tires and fuel on lap 25 and spun while exiting his pit box, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips was taken to the infield care center for treatment, receiving stitches for a cut on his leg and was later released. Drake did not finish the race and ended up 23rd. Many cars in the race struggled with traction due to rainfall before the green flag.

In Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, brutally murdered his wife, dancer Cicera Alves de Sena, 29, after only four days of marriage. The incident was captured on CCTV, showing Severiano dragging de Sena's limp body into their apartment's garden, repeatedly smashing her head into concrete 11 times, and punching her 10 times. He then returned with a handgun and shot her five times at point-blank range. Severiano confessed to the crime, stating his jealousy over men looking at his wife was the motive. De Sena, known by her stage name Amanda Bueno, was a member of the dance troupe Jaula das Gostozuedas. Neighbors reported hearing a terrible argument and gunshots. Severiano was later arrested after crashing a stolen car and was found with multiple firearms and a bullet-proof vest in the vehicle. He now faces life in prison.

Sarah Wilson, a 41-year-old journalist and author of the best-selling book "I Quit Sugar," has disclosed her personal struggle with mental illness, specifically anxiety and depression. In a candid interview with Women's Weekly Australia, she revealed that her anxiety led her to a point where she couldn't see the purpose of continuing her life. The combination of mounting stress, her thyroid disease, and feelings of isolation due to not having a husband or children exacerbated her situation. Wilson described feeling "very alone" and unable to find a way out. She has since found some peace with her condition, acknowledging that she is an "anxious person." Wilson believes that depression and anxiety are intrinsically linked and that recognizing this connection is crucial for better managing these issues. She notes that anxiety is becoming the "new depression," a sentiment supported by Beyond Blue's report that one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime. Wilson emphasizes the importance of seeking help if needed, directing individuals to contact Beyond Blue on 1300 224 636 or Lifeline on 13 11 14.

Elena Curtin, a seven-months pregnant woman from Portland, Oregon, was charged with second-degree assault in November 2014 after she attacked her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar. The ex-girlfriend was found using heroin in Curtin's bathroom, and despite being asked to leave, she refused. Curtin, who was set to go to trial, will no longer face prosecution as the charge was dropped due to her actions being deemed "completely justified in her outrage" under Oregon law, which allows for physical force against intruders who refuse to leave a resident's home. The ex-girlfriend had a history of harassing and threatening Curtin, and the boyfriend, who is the father of Curtin's child, had struggled with heroin in the past. If convicted, Curtin could have faced a mandatory prison sentence of nearly six years. Curtin gave birth in January following the incident, and she and her boyfriend are no longer involved. The ex-girlfriend and the boyfriend have since reconciled and have a five-year-old child together.

Gemma, a pit bull from California, was filmed being fed treats by her owner. In an attempt to trick her, the owner included a piece of broccoli. Gemma displayed a clear dislike for the vegetable, pulling a disgusted face and spitting it out on the floor. The owner hopes that the two children Gemma lives with will not mimic her behavior and learn to enjoy their greens. When not eating, Gemma enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC has apologized for a significant blunder on its official website. A link on the page for the Young Entrepreneur Awards, which was discontinued in 2011, directed visitors to a pornographic site. This occurred because the organizers allowed the registration of the awards' URL on hsbc.com.hk to expire, allowing a porn site to take over the address. The bank removed the hyperlink after discovering the mistake and clarified that it has no association with the external site. HSBC assured the public that its internet banking services remain secure and unaffected by this incident.

A 13-year-old boy named Marcus from Maryland made a 911 call after a fire broke out in his family's home in Clinton on Sunday morning. Marcus and his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah were trapped in a second-floor bedroom due to the heat in the hallway. Marcus remained calm throughout the 11-minute call, providing directions to the 911 dispatcher. He reassured his sister, who was distressed, and instructed her to stay low and breathe. Prince George's County firefighters entered the home through a back door and broke a window to rescue Marcus and Aaliyah. Lieutenant Kenny Ward handed Marcus out the window to another rescuer and later gave his gas mask to Aaliyah. Both siblings were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries. The other family members, who were also in the house, escaped on their own and were taken to MedStar Hospital.

Photographer Andy Hutchinson captured stunning images of blue fluorescent algae illuminating Jervis Bay, a popular beach on the south coast of New South Wales, Australia. This natural phenomenon, described by Hutchinson as a "beautiful supernatural scene," is caused by millions of plankton emitting light. A similar event occurred in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014. Iain Suthers, an oceanography expert from the University of New South Wales, explained that the glow is produced by Noctiluca scintillans, a single-celled phytoplankton that blooms in spring and autumn. This carnivorous algae preys on diatoms and emits light as a defense mechanism. Suthers reassured that such blooms are typically due to natural causes and pose no threat.

New genetic tests are enabling breast cancer patients to avoid chemotherapy by identifying'markers' in the tumor that determine its aggressiveness. After surgery, cancer cells are analyzed in a lab to assess the risk of recurrence within days. For some women, the test can accurately predict a low risk, as low as 5%, which is comparable to or better than the odds for those who undergo chemotherapy. Currently, most breast cancer patients receive chemotherapy post-surgery to prevent recurrence, despite the severe side effects such as hair loss, nausea, fatigue, and weight changes.

The tests, like Endopredict, can help women make informed decisions about their treatment. If a patient receives a low score, they can opt out of chemotherapy. These tests are currently available privately at a cost of around £2,500, but breast specialists hope they will soon be accessible on the NHS. Surgeons argue that the cost of the test could be offset by savings from not administering chemotherapy.

Becca Cornford, a 49-year-old mother of three, was diagnosed and treated for breast cancer last year and later found cancer in her other breast. She dreaded chemotherapy more than another mastectomy, fearing it would hinder her ability to care for her children. Professor Kefah Mokbel, her surgeon, used the Endopredict test on her tumor sample, which revealed a 5% risk of recurrence within ten years. Chemotherapy could not offer significantly better odds, so Becca decided against it, opting for regular monitoring instead.

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy over the past nine years, as revealed by a Freedom of Information request. HMS Ocean had five pregnant sailors removed in emergency evacuations, and HMS Illustrious, nicknamed 'HMS Lusty', also had at least one pregnant sailor airlifted before its decommissioning. Eighteen other ships, including HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise, and HMS Richmond, also had emergency evacuations due to pregnancy. The strict 'no touching' rule on ships suggests that most pregnancies occurred before boarding or during leave. 

The data comes nine months after Commander Sarah West, the first female to captain a Royal Navy warship, was flown back to the UK following claims of a sexual relationship with a crew member. An investigation was launched into her conduct, and she was replaced by an unnamed captain. 

Women have been serving on Royal Navy ships since 1990, with around 9% of personnel being female in 2014. In May of the same year, three women made history as the first female submariners to serve in the Royal Navy. 

In a separate context, nearly 100 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan after discovering they were pregnant between 2006 and 2013. Sixteen women were removed from Afghanistan in 2013, and 18 were sent home in 2011. A further 102 women were evacuated from Iraq. Strict military rules prohibit pregnant women from serving in war zones, and they are flown back on flights usually reserved for injured troops. The true figure of pregnancies could be higher if others traveled via routine flights.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive cesium was discovered on the rooftop of Japan's Prime Minister's residence in Tokyo, raising concerns about potential terrorism involving drones. The drone, equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing cesium, was found on the same day a Japanese court approved the restart of two reactors at the Sendai nuclear power plant, a decision met with public opposition due to safety concerns following the Fukushima disaster. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, who was in Indonesia at the time, emphasized the need for continuous examination and review of drone operation regulations to prevent future terrorism threats. Currently, there are no flight restrictions for drones in most of Tokyo, including government buildings.

Lu Xincai, a security guard from Zhejiang Province, China, has garnered attention for his dedication to caring for his 84-year-old mother, who suffers from Alzheimer's disease. Fearing she might get lost if left alone, Lu brings her to work on the back of his motorbike every day. He ties a sash around their waists to ensure her safety during the four-kilometer journey, which takes about an hour. His employers, a bank, have provided her with her own room. Lu's commitment stems from his mother's lifelong dedication to caring for her children, and he feels a duty to reciprocate. Despite his wife working in a different city and his son being in school, Lu prioritizes his mother's well-being, stating, "I was an apple in my mum's eye, and now she's my apple."

A major study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington, published in the American Journal of Public Health, reveals a significant rise in heavy drinking and binge-drinking among Americans between 2005 and 2012. The study, which tracked adult drinking patterns at the county level for the first time, found that heavy drinking increased by 17.2%, primarily due to rising rates among women. The CDC defines heavy drinking as exceeding one drink per day for women and two for men over the past month, while binge drinking is defined as four or more drinks for women and five for men on a single occasion at least once in the past month.

The study indicates that women's binge drinking rates rose by nearly 36% in Santa Clara County, California, between 2002 and 2012, compared to 23% among men. Nationwide, women's binge drinking increased more than seven times the rate among men. The reasons for this shift include changing social norms, making it more socially acceptable for women to drink like men, and the influx of wealthy professionals in cities like San Francisco, San Jose, and Oakland, many of whom work in high-stress, high-party tech jobs.

The study also highlights that despite the increase in heavy drinking, the percentage of people who drink any alcohol has remained relatively unchanged. In 2012, 8% of Americans were considered heavy drinkers, and 18% were binge drinkers. The researchers note that about 88,600 U.S. deaths were attributed to alcohol in 2010, and the cost of excessive drinking has been estimated at more than $220 billion per year.

Public health experts suggest that the increase in excessive drinking can be attributed to various factors, including the affordability of alcohol due to stagnant taxes, increased alcohol advertising, and weakened alcohol control policies.

The World Health Organization (WHO), the United Nations' public health agency, has warned that doctors in England are performing caesarean sections too frequently, putting the health of women and their babies at risk. The WHO recommends that the caesarean rate should ideally be between 10% and 15%, but currently, over a quarter of women in England are delivering via caesarean, a rate that has more than doubled since the early 1990s. This increase includes a growing number of women opting for planned caesareans due to anxiety about natural childbirth.

The WHO statement contradicts current NHS guidelines, which allow caesareans even without medical justification, such as for women with tokophobia, previous complicated births, advanced maternal age, or certain medical conditions. The WHO emphasizes that while caesareans can save lives, they often occur without medical necessity, leading to short- and long-term health problems, disability, or even death. The procedure also diverts resources from other patients. A planned caesarean costs the NHS an average of £2,369, compared to £1,665 for a natural birth. Previous research indicates that up to one in ten caesareans result in infections.

A woman named Michelle Filkins, 44, from West Wareham, has been arrested for breaking into a home on Martha's Vineyard, living there for at least a week, and selling the homeowners' belongings at a yard sale. Filkins was discovered by the homeowner, Mark Conklin, on April 17 in his Court Street property in Edgartown. She was charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. Conklin found Filkins in his living room, and when confronted, she claimed ownership of the house. She fled in a gray Nissan pickup truck when Conklin called the police. Police later arrested her after she attempted to re-enter the house, believing Conklin had left. Items reported missing include various household items, a Weber grill, and a painting by the owner. The police are asking anyone who received items from the home to return them, and are offering assistance to those who unknowingly purchased stolen goods. Filkins is scheduled to appear in court on May 14.

Bella Crooke, a resident of Melbourne, lost her unlocked iPhone at a friend's birthday party on Saturday night. The phone was handed in to Albury Police Station on the NSW-Victoria border the following morning. Police officers, realizing the phone was unlocked, used it to post selfies and humorous photos on Bella's Facebook page, including one of the phone in a "holding cell." They also posted updates and puns, reassuring Bella that her phone was safe and fully charged. The posts gained traction among Bella's friends, who praised the police for their creative approach. When Bella arrived at the police station, officers recognized her from her Facebook page and returned the phone without requiring her to provide identification. Bella, appreciative of the police's humor and efficient service, has since put a password on her phone.

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was tragically killed in a fight between two adult males at the Isimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa. The calf's mother, who had been protecting it from younger hippos, watched in horror as one of the adults grabbed the calf between its jaws. Despite the mother's attempts to retrieve her baby, the sub-adult hippo tightened its grip, causing the calf to be flung into the air. The baby hippo died hours later from its injuries. The exact motive behind the attack remains unclear, whether it was intentional, play, or jealousy.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, one of the most expensive areas to live in Britain, is on the market for £575,000. However, the property comes with a significant catch: it has only three years left on its lease. This would equate to a yearly cost of £191,000 or a monthly cost of £15,000, roughly the same as renting a three-bedroom flat in the area. The unmodernized maisonette, located in exclusive Egerton Place, spans 1,990 sq/ft and includes three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, and utility room, along with amenities like a lift, parking, and a communal garden.

If a buyer decides to extend the lease, the property could potentially be worth upwards of £6 million. The current freeholder is believed to be the Welcome Trust, and extending the lease would likely cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million for a 90-year extension. The properties in Egerton Place were built in 1893 and are known for their high-quality architecture. Despite the short lease, the property has generated significant interest, with potential buyers including locals, developers, and end-users. However, property consultant Alex Newall warns that the cost of extending the lease will be substantial, making it a "very quirky situation."

Starbucks experienced a nationwide computer outage on Friday evening that affected 8,000 stores in the U.S. and Canada, causing registers to malfunction. This led to baristas offering free drinks and baked goods to customers. The outage began in the early evening on the East Coast and late afternoon on the West Coast. The company did not disclose the exact cause but stated it was due to a failure during a daily system refresh. The issue affected company-operated stores and Evolution Fresh and Teavana stores. While many customers enjoyed the free products, some stores closed early or for the night to avoid giving away free items. The outage came just a day after Starbucks reported record quarterly earnings of $4.6 billion, with shares gaining 4.4% to $51.50 following the announcement.

Terrorists are reportedly undergoing training in rural areas of West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire. This information was disclosed by Detective Constable Gareth Jones from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit. The training activities are often disguised as ordinary community activities, but they serve a radicalization purpose. The issue of terrorism is not confined to urban areas, as evidenced by incidents dating back to 1998 when Abu Hamza allegedly sent extremists to train in the Brecon Beacons. 

The rugged terrain of these areas, used by the British military for training, has also been exploited by terrorists. For instance, two of the 7/7 bombers were photographed white water rafting in Bala, North Wales. In 2010, three Cardiff men were arrested for plotting an al-Qaeda inspired 'Mumbai-style' terror attacks. Michael Adebowale, convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby, studied Arabic at the European Institute of Human Sciences in Highmead, near Llanybydder, reportedly set up by Iraqi clerics. 

Jones emphasized the importance of community intelligence, urging the community to report any suspicious activities to the authorities.

A juvenile female Omura's whale, a species previously feared extinct, was discovered on a remote Exmouth beach in Western Australia following Tropical Cyclone Olwyn. This marks the first sighting in Western Australia and only the second in Australia. The identification was initially challenging for the Department of Parks and Wildlife staff, but DNA profiling confirmed it to be an Omura's whale. This find is significant as very little is known about the species, which was first described in scientific journals in 2003 and is typically found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The whale has a sleek body shape and unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin. The carcass has been buried, and the skeleton will be recovered for further scientific investigation and potential public display in museums. The data gathered from this whale will aid in improving field identification guides and understanding the species' regional distribution.

The passage discusses the controversial viewpoint of Cheryl Rios, CEO of Go Ape Marketing, who believes that Hillary Clinton should not be president due to the potential impact of her hormones on decision-making, specifically starting an unnecessary war. The author counters this argument by highlighting that women leaders, particularly postmenopausal women like Clinton, are less likely to take unnecessary risks, as supported by scientific studies. The author also points out historical examples of male leaders whose decisions were influenced negatively by their hormones.

The debate over Clinton's hormones is seen as a symptom of deeper-rooted gender bias in the workplace. Despite women outnumbering men in higher education and the workforce, they still face significant barriers to leadership roles. The bias is both overt, as seen in the underrepresentation of women on corporate boards, and covert, as evidenced by gender-based descriptions of professors.

The author argues that this bias is detrimental not only to women but to society as a whole, as gender equality benefits companies, families, and the economy. Companies with more women in leadership roles perform better financially, children with involved fathers are happier and more successful, and diverse teams produce superior results. The author concludes by emphasizing the need to support women in leadership roles, despite societal biases, for the betterment of all.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, known for his roles in "All Creatures Great and Small" and for frequently portraying Winston Churchill, is auctioning off his extensive collection of antiques valued at £100,000. The 89-year-old, a military historian and expert on the medieval longbow, is downsizing his home and collection. The auction, held by Dominic Winter Auctioneers in Gloucestershire, includes over 200 items such as furniture, paintings, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, and crystal chandeliers. Notable pieces include a hand-painted limewood diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a longbow with a mother-of-pearl handle, and a portrait of Hardy holding the longbow. Hardy, who studied English with J.R.R. Tolkien and C.S. Lewis, has published books on the history of the longbow and was consulted during the raising of the Mary Rose. He expressed sadness over downsizing his treasured library but hopes the new owners will find joy in his possessions. The auction, featuring 238 lots, will take place on Saturday.

Michael Scott Shemansky, a Florida man, is currently a fugitive after being named as a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, 57. The body was found at their shared home in Winter Garden after an out-of-state family member requested a well-being check. Shemansky failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother was discovered dead. Police suspect foul play and have the murder weapon, though the method of killing has not been disclosed. Shemansky, who is on parole for battery on law enforcement and has a history of bipolar mental illness, was involuntarily committed to a psychiatric ward for an attempted suicide. Neighbors believe the stress of divorce proceedings, which his mother was helping him navigate, may have triggered the incident. Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot from the trailer park where he was staying, without provisions or medication. His estranged wife, who has a domestic violence injunction against him, is preparing for his potential return. Authorities urge anyone with information about his whereabouts to contact them.

The city of Eugene, United States, has been selected to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. This decision was made by the International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) Council, bypassing the usual bidding process due to the perceived 'unique strategic opportunity' to host the event in the USA for the first time. Eugene had previously unsuccessfully bid for the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha, Qatar. IAAF President Lamine Diack emphasized the strategic importance of this decision, highlighting the collaboration between public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and the enthusiastic public. This choice deviates from the standard procedure, but is seen as beneficial for the global development of athletics. Notably, the 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan, was also awarded without a bidding process. The passage also mentions Mo Farah's gold medal win in the men's 10000 meters at the 2013 IAAF World Athletics Championships in Moscow.

Aspiring model Leonie Granger, 25, from Gillingham, Kent, has been sentenced to 16 years in prison for the manslaughter of professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56. Granger lured Hassan, whom she met at a London casino, to his flat with the intention of robbing him. She befriended Hassan, who showered her with gifts and cash, and then left the flat unlocked for her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson, 28, and an accomplice, Nicholas Chandler, 29, to enter. The two men tied up Hassan, beat him to death, and ransacked his home, stealing £3,000, his TV, and mobile phone. Granger was found guilty of manslaughter but not murder, while Jackson and Chandler were found guilty of murder and sentenced to life in prison with a minimum term of 36 years. The judge described the attack as "pitiless and wicked," emphasizing its brutal nature. Granger's defense argued that she was in love with Jackson and was manipulated into the scheme, but the judge noted her deceitfulness and loss of compassion. The case also involved two counts of plotting to rob employees of Grosvenor Casinos and conspiracy to falsely imprison. Hassan's family expressed their grief, stating that his death will "haunt them forever."

Cesc Fabregas, Chelsea's midfielder, has been experiencing a decline in form during the second half of the season, as evidenced by his performance in Spain's 2-0 defeat to the Netherlands. Despite his initial brilliance, which included a strong chance of breaking the Premier League record for assists, his contributions have significantly decreased since mid-January. This trend aligns with his history at Barcelona, where his performance also tapered off towards the end of each season. Fabregas, who has only one assist in his last five Premier League games, was rated poorly in Spain's match against the Netherlands. His fatigue from a long, intense campaign is a concern for Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho, especially as the team aims to secure the Premier League title. However, with nine games left, including matches against teams Fabregas has previously assisted, there is still hope for a late-season resurgence that could help Chelsea clinch the title.

West Ham United is in negotiations to sign 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, who has impressed during a trial period with the club's academy. Beckford, from Montego Bay United, has also received offers from Belgian clubs and is considered one of the most promising prospects from the Caribbean. Meanwhile, West Ham has announced that season tickets for the 2016-17 season at their new Olympic Stadium will start at £289, making it the cheapest in the Premier League, as they aim to fill the 54,000-capacity stadium.

Wiltshire police have discontinued their investigation into the violent assault of Mike Lane, a 40-year-old huntsman, despite substantial evidence. The attack, which occurred on January 24 near Amesbury, involved balaclava-clad protesters armed with iron bars on ropes. Lane was beaten, knocked unconscious, and suffered concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss. A video of the incident and a dossier containing names and car registration numbers of suspects were provided to the police. However, due to insufficient evidence, the police have shelved the inquiry, a decision that has been widely condemned by hunt supporters and Lane himself, who feels let down by the police. The Countryside Alliance is advocating for a ban on saboteurs wearing face coverings to aid in identifying and prosecuting offenders. Wiltshire police stated that the case is currently recorded as undetected but could be reopened if new evidence emerges.

Adam Gadahn, also known as Azzam the American, was a prominent member of Al Qaeda and its chief English-language propagandist. Born in 1978 in California, he converted to Islam in 1995 and moved to Pakistan in 1998, where he joined Al Qaeda. He was indicted in 2006 for treason and material support to Al Qaeda. Gadahn appeared in numerous Al Qaeda videos, threatening attacks on the U.S. and Western targets, and urging Muslims to target American, Western, and Jewish interests. He was known for his criticism of U.S. presidents and his calls for lone-wolf attacks in the U.S. Gadahn was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January, though he was not specifically targeted. He was married to a woman from Afghanistan and had at least one child. His final video was posted in September 2014.

A five-year-old Chinese boy named Mai Zizhuo has gained viral fame in China for his exceptional basketball skills. Mai has been practicing since he was two and a half years old. A video of him showcases his ability to score hoops and dribble two basketballs simultaneously, leaving viewers in awe. His talent has earned him numerous fans across the country, with many netizens expressing disbelief and admiration. The video has sparked reactions ranging from skepticism about special effects to feelings of inadequacy among adult viewers. Mai's skills have been compared to those of Yao Ming, China's most renowned basketball star, who played in the NBA for the Houston Rockets from 2002 to 2011.

Tom O'Carroll, a former key activist for the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), a group that campaigned to legalize child sex in the 1970s and 80s, has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. O'Carroll, a former Open University information officer, attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25 to advocate for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off, established in response to the phone-hacking scandal, opposes the Independent Press Standards Organisation (IPSO) and advocates for a statutory body to regulate the press, as suggested by the Leveson Inquiry. O'Carroll's involvement with Hacked Off is likely to be embarrassing for the group, given PIE's history. PIE was formed in 1974 to legalize sex with children and also advocated for lowering the age of consent to ten if the child understood the act. O'Carroll was part of the NCCL's gay rights sub-committee and was imprisoned in 1981 for corrupting public morals. He confirmed his attendance at the February meeting, chaired by John Cleese, in a subsequent blog post. A Hacked Off spokesman stated that the meeting was open to the public.

On Thursday, Bondi Beach's iconic Icebergs Club pool was drained for a unique fashion show during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The empty pool served as an unusual catwalk for the ten-piece presentation by the label Mono, a unisex clothing line designed by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and his partner Lucy Hinckfuss. The monochrome collection, designed to be worn in 20 different ways, was showcased with models walking through the concrete pool and along the break wall, offering a stunning ocean backdrop. The event attracted a crowd, including beachgoers and passersby, who enjoyed the sunny weather on an unseasonably warm day. Guests were treated to food and drinks from Icebergs and Santa Vittoria while viewing the minimalist, androgynous designs.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan and his family, including his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa, enjoyed a day at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom in Northern California. During their visit, Khan posed for photos and fed a rare white tiger, as well as interacting with giraffes and sea lions. Earlier in the week, Khan announced his next fight will be against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation about potential bouts with British rival Kell Brook and other boxers like Adrien Broner and Keith Thurman.

Mohammed Abu Khdeir, a 16-year-old Palestinian teenager, was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July. His name was mistakenly included on a memorial wall at Jerusalem's Mount Herzl, which honors fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism. Abu Khdeir's family and Almagor, an organization representing victims of terror, objected to his inclusion, arguing that his death was a rogue attack, not an act of terrorism. Almagor's CEO, Meir Indor, demanded the removal of Abu Khdeir's name from the memorial, stating that his organization would remove their own family members' names if the teen's name was not taken off. Following the father's complaints, the National Insurance Institute of Israel agreed to remove Abu Khdeir's name from the memorial. The three suspects in Abu Khdeir's killing are currently undergoing a trial.

In a California-based YouTube video, user Lionel Hutz filmed his young son attempting to use their family cat as a pillow. The footage shows the cat licking its fur when the boy jumps on top of it. After a brief moment of stillness, the cat gets up and moves to another spot. The boy follows, repeating the process twice more before the cat finally has enough and goes indoors. Despite the initial incident, a later video shows the boy gently feeding the cat treats, indicating they have reconciled.

A police corruption trial in Philadelphia is ongoing, with one witness, Robert Kushner, already facing consequences for his testimony. Kushner, 32, lost his coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after admitting to years of marijuana dealing. He is among over a dozen former drug dealers testifying for the federal government, alleging police wrongdoing. Kushner claimed that some of the officers on trial stole $81,000 and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest, which he said was later expunged. However, he was arrested again in 2011 and sentenced to four years of probation, and pleaded guilty to a DUI in 2008. Kushner maintains his innocence in the 2011 charges and expresses remorse for deceiving the school. The defense lawyers for the six former drug squad officers accused of racketeering argue that the government's case is based on testimonies from 19 lying drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

An explosion at a chemical plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian Province, China, sparked a large fire, injuring six people, five of whom were treated for glass injuries. The plant produces paraxylene (PX), a potentially carcinogenic chemical used in polyester production. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility following an oil leak, though no toxic chemical spill was reported. Over 600 firefighters controlled the blaze. The plant was previously relocated from Xiamen in 2007 due to pollution concerns. It had another explosion in July 2013 with no reported casualties or toxic leaks. The construction of PX plants has sparked protests in several Chinese cities.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa teenager and Ireland Under-21 international, has a superstition about wearing his socks low, just above his shinpads. Despite Premier League referees advising him to "pull his socks up," Grealish insists he will continue this practice. He uses children's shinpads, which he claims have never been kicked. Grealish made his first Premier League start in Aston Villa's 3-3 draw against QPR, a tough match in a relegation battle. He expressed satisfaction with the start, despite the draw, and hopes for more opportunities under the manager's faith in him.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, the 22-year-old daughter of Bobby Brown and the late Whitney Houston, is currently in a critical condition with "global and irreversible brain damage," according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston. Despite no longer being in a medically induced coma, Bobbi Kristina remains unresponsive to visitors and familiar voices, and her eyes do not follow movement. She has a tracheostomy and is undergoing rehabilitation, which her family's attorney, Christopher Brown, stated will be a long and challenging process. The quality of her future life remains uncertain. Bobby Brown had previously reported improvements in his daughter's condition, stating she was awake and watching him, but this was later clarified by his wife, Alicia Etheredge-Brown, who said he was in an emotional state during his remarks.

Russia is on the verge of securing a spot in the Fed Cup final after leading Germany 2-0. Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point against Sabine Lisicki, ultimately winning the match 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3. Earlier, Svetlana Kuznetsova defeated Julia Goerges in straight sets. Both players struggled with their serves, with Pavlyuchenkova committing 13 double faults and Lisicki making 63 unforced errors. Russia needs just one win from Sunday's three matches to clinch their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales, still recovering from last week's severe weather, are being warned of another storm expected to hit later this week, potentially causing more floods and damage. Meteorologists predict an east coast low, similar to the one that battered the state's east coast for three days last week, could return, bringing heavy rain from Thursday through Saturday. The State Emergency Service (SES) is currently dealing with over 24,000 requests for assistance, with more than 4,000 jobs still pending. SES spokeswoman Stephanie Wills expressed concern that additional storms could hinder clean-up efforts, particularly in the hard-hit Hunter region. The weather system is expected to bring heavy rainfall and strong winds, raising flood levels and causing further tree damage. While the new weather system may not affect Sydney as severely as the previous one, it could still bring significant rainfall to coastal areas in the state's northeast, including the Northern Rivers and Mid North Coasts, as well as southeast Queensland. The Bureau of Meteorology warns that further rainfall is likely for catchments that have already experienced flooding. The SES is working to complete as many jobs as possible before the next storm hits and is urging the community to prepare their homes and families to prevent further loss and devastation.

Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model, has refuted claims that she attempted suicide, as reported by Italian media. Instead, she stated that she was hospitalized due to low blood pressure after a domestic accident where she fell and hit her head, resulting in bruises all over her body. Moric, who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" music video, shared photos of her injuries on her Instagram account, which has over 40,000 followers. She clarified that her boyfriend, Luigi Mario Favoloso, was in Naples at the time of the incident and not present at their Milan apartment. Moric expressed shock at the suicide claims and assured her fans that she is recovering well and only needs rest. Previously, Italian media had reported a suicide attempt by Moric in 2009 due to an overdose. Moric was previously married to Fabrizio Corona, a notorious paparazzi photographer who was jailed for blackmailing celebrities with compromising photos.

Kate and William, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, are preparing for the arrival of their second child, and the British public is eagerly anticipating the name they will choose. According to a YouGov poll for The Sunday Times, if the baby is a girl, Diana, named after William's mother, the late Princess of Wales, is the favorite choice, with 12% of respondents preferring it. Alice and Charlotte follow closely, each with 9% of the votes. Alice is the name of the Queen's aunt, and Charlotte is a nod to William's father, Charles. If the baby is a boy, James and Alexander are the top choices, with 13% and 12% of the votes, respectively. A quarter of the 2,200 people polled expressed a desire for a girl, while only 3% hoped for a boy. The poll also showed that 68% of people supported William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job. Social media users have also been expressing their preferences, with many hoping for a girl named Diana.

A suicide bomber attacked a group of protesters in Khost, eastern Afghanistan on Thursday, killing 17 people and injuring 64 others, including Afghan lawmaker Humayoon Humayoon. The attack occurred around 10 a.m. local time as the protesters were en route to join a larger rally against the provincial governor. Taliban spokesman Zabiullah Mujahid denied the group's involvement, and no other organization has claimed responsibility yet. CNN's Masoud Popalzai reported from Kabul, and Jethro Mullen wrote from Hong Kong, with contributions from Elizabeth Joseph.

Dani Alves, the 31-year-old Brazilian right-back, is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. Alves has had a successful seven-year stint at Barcelona, winning four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice. His agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, confirmed that Alves turned down a three-year contract extension, which was contingent on him participating in 60% of the club's matches. The negotiations are now concluded, according to Santana, who expressed disappointment at the timing of the offer, noting that it was quite late in the season for such discussions.

Pablo Osvaldo, a 29-year-old striker currently on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton, has expressed his desire for Italian football legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentinian club. Osvaldo, who has scored three goals in six games for Boca, believes that both players would fit well in the team due to their South American-style play. He suggests that the fans would adore having Pirlo and Totti on the La Bombonera pitch. Pirlo, renowned as one of the best midfielders globally, and Totti, a Roma legend, are both highly respected in world football. Osvaldo, having played with many great players, considers Pirlo and Totti his top choices to join him at Boca Juniors.

Eighteen-year-old amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson experienced a dramatic fall from his horse, Merrion Square, during a race at Wincanton. Despite the spectacular double somersault, Ferguson only sustained a minor cut on his nose. He was back to his regular duties at Paul Nicholls' yard the following day, mucking out stables as usual. Ferguson expressed that he couldn't recall the incident until he watched the replay, and his fellow jockeys described it as one of the most impressive falls they had seen. He received some teasing from his peers but also gained hundreds of new Twitter followers. Ferguson remains undeterred and humorously considered a career in gymnastics due to his acrobatic fall.

James Haskell, the London Wasps captain and England flanker, posted an Instagram photo dressed as Iron Man, coinciding with the release of the new Avengers: Age of Ultron movie. The movie premiered at Westfield London shopping centre, with fans eagerly waiting to see the star-studded cast including Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth, and Scarlett Johansson. Haskell, who returned to Wasps in 2012 after stints with Stade Francais, Ricoh Black Rams, and Highlanders in New Zealand, posted the image with the caption, "#TransformYourself #IWill #AvengersAgeOfUltron". Since his return to Wasps, Haskell has made over 100 appearances for the club and has become a significant member of the England squad, earning 57 caps.

The passage discusses the resurgence of wide-leg trousers in the Spring/Summer 2015 (SS15) fashion trends. These trousers, available in various materials like denim, cropped, printed, or striped, offer a refreshing alternative to the long-dominant skinny jeans. Louise Redknapp, a fashion influencer, endorses the wide-leg trouser as a welcome change from skinny jeans. The trend has cycled back since the 1970s, with Redknapp herself having previously worn a Stella McCartney flared jean seven years ago.

Despite potential intimidation, especially for those who are shorter, the key to styling wide-leg trousers is in the choice of footwear. High heels with exposed tops of the foot can elongate the leg, making the voluminous trousers more flattering. Simple tops, such as knits, shirts, or tees, are recommended to maintain a current and cool look.

Denim is identified as the easiest way to adopt this trend, with Gucci's SS15 collection featuring vintage-washed flared jeans. Other brands like Celine and Stella McCartney have also showcased dressier wide-leg pants, while Topshop offers a more affordable version called the Miller jean. Finery London provides a similar style at a lower price point.

The passage concludes by emphasizing that the wide-leg trouser trend is versatile and doesn't require good weather, making it a practical addition to any wardrobe. For more inspiration and shopping options, readers are directed to AStyleAlbum.com. Poppy Delevingne's AW15 Chloe show appearance in Paris is cited as an example of the trend's popularity.

The University of Michigan has decided to screen the film "American Sniper" despite objections from over 200 students. The movie, starring Bradley Cooper as Chris Kyle, a Navy SEAL and the deadliest U.S. military sniper, was initially targeted due to concerns that its portrayal of the Iraq War might negatively stereotype the Middle East. This decision was made in a campus with a significant Arab-American population. However, following a backlash and a counter-petition, the university reversed its decision, citing its commitment to freedom of expression and students' right to choose. The university will also offer an alternative screening of the family-friendly film "Paddington" for those who prefer not to attend "American Sniper." The decision was praised by Michigan's head football coach, Jim Harbaugh.

Two French tourists, aged 18 and 24, were charged with animal cruelty after attempting to set a quokka, an Australian marsupial, on fire on Rottnest Island off Perth, Western Australia, on April 3. The incident occurred when they ignited an aerosol spray with a lighter, causing a large flame to burn the quokka. Despite the severity of the injury, the quokka survived and was singed. The men, who are from Cockburn Central, were questioned by detectives, evicted from the island, and seized video evidence of their act. They will appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. Quokkas, the size of a domestic cat, are native to small islands off the West Australian coast, particularly Rottnest Island and Bald Island near Albany.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old former dancer from the 1930s and 1940s, had never seen herself perform until recently. She was a part of chorus lines in New York nightclubs like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar, often dancing alongside famous figures such as Bill "Bojangles" Robinson and Frank Sinatra. Despite her appearances in motion pictures, she had never watched them. Additionally, her photographs and memorabilia were lost over the years. Filmmaker Mark Cantor and volunteers from jazz-on-film.com created a video compilation of "Soundies" - early music videos featuring Barker. They showed this to her at her nursing home, and she was delighted, describing it as "fabulous."

The passage discusses a decline in the tradition of washing one's own car in Britain, as revealed by a study conducted by vehicle leasing firm OSV. Thirty-one percent of men and 75% of women have never washed their own car, with only 12% of those who do it, doing so regularly. Factors contributing to this decline include Sunday shopping and increased live football coverage, which discourage people from doing chores on weekends. The rise of hand car washes and the size of 4x4 vehicles also make self-washing less appealing. During holidays, however, an estimated 15 million cars were washed by their owners, with one in four admitting they only do it to leave the house. Cars are most frequently washed by their owners in Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield, and least in Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh. Audi, Toyota, and BMW owners are more likely to wash their cars, while Range Rover, Peugeot, and Mercedes owners are less likely. OSV spokesman Andrew Kirkley attributes this shift to lack of time, larger cars, and the availability of affordable professional car washing services.

Martin Skrtel, Liverpool's defender, has praised Steven Gerrard's impact on his career since the latter's arrival at Anfield in 2008. Skrtel acknowledges Gerrard as one of the best players globally and a synonymous figure with Liverpool. Gerrard is set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley on Sunday, aiming to lead his hometown club to the final against Arsenal on his birthday, May 30. If Liverpool wins against Villa, Gerrard will conclude his Anfield career in the final before moving to LA Galaxy. Skrtel, who joined Liverpool from Zenit St Petersburg seven years ago, credits Gerrard for his support during his early days at the club. Although Skrtel recognizes that Liverpool will be different without Gerrard, he believes the team has potential replacements for the iconic number 8, provided they receive the right guidance. Both Skrtel and Gerrard could return to the Liverpool lineup for the match against Villa after serving three-match bans for violent conduct in March.

At the age of 75, golf legend Jack Nicklaus made a hole-in-one during the par-3 contest at Augusta National, adding another memorable moment to his illustrious career. This was Nicklaus' first hole-in-one on the hallowed grounds of Augusta, a feat that was matched by Camilo Villegas later in the day, resulting in a record-tying five aces. Nicklaus, who won his first Masters in 1963 and his sixth in 1986, was playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. Despite Villegas' impressive performance, including two aces, he lost the title in a playoff to Kevin Streelman. Nicklaus, one of five golfers to achieve a career grand slam, humorously mentioned his earlier prediction of winning the par-3 contest.

On Wednesday night, tornado sirens sounded in Kansas as multiple storms produced reports of twisters. A tornado was spotted approximately 6 miles northwest of Goddard, near Wichita, but it missed the city, posing risks to other communities. CNN's Chad Myers warned that storms would continue throughout the night, emphasizing that nighttime tornadoes are particularly dangerous. Additional tornado sightings were reported in southwestern Kansas, near Aetna. The storms also affected Missouri, with a potential tornado touchdown in Potosi, about 70 miles from St. Louis. Potosi experienced wind damage, flooding, and hail as large as baseballs. More severe weather is forecasted for the midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

Reserve Deputy Robert Bates, 73, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting Eric Harris, whom he intended to subdue with a taser. The incident occurred during a weapons sting operation on April 2. Bates claims the shooting was accidental and has apologized to the Harris family. The judge allowed Bates to go on a family vacation to the Bahamas, a decision criticized by the Harris family as insensitive. Bates' lawyer stated that the preliminary hearing on July 2 will provide an opportunity to present facts in court. The Harris family's lawyer alleges Bates was unqualified for the force, receiving preferential treatment due to donations and friendship with the sheriff. The Tulsa World newspaper reported that some supervisors were asked to falsify Bates' records, a claim the sheriff's office denies. Two deputies involved in Harris' arrest have been reassigned due to threats against them and their families. Bates' lawyer released his training documents, asserting he had proper law enforcement training.

Conor McGregor, a 26-year-old Irish MMA fighter, is preparing for a featherweight title challenge against Jose Aldo on July 11 in Las Vegas. McGregor has recently unveiled a new tattoo of a tiger on his stomach, adding to his existing gorilla-themed chest tattoo. He claims Aldo lacks the same motivation for this fight, which will be Aldo's eighth title defense. McGregor asserts that Aldo does not want the belt as much as he does, a claim supported by an incident during their promotional tour in Dublin where McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt and raised it in front of 5,000 home supporters. The two fighters have a contentious relationship, and McGregor is confident he will win the title and prove his superior motivation.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott faced criticism from anti-drinking campaigners after he skolled a beer at an Australian Rules function, cheered by about 50 attendees. Cultural studies professor Julie Robert from the University of Technology Sydney deemed it problematic, as she believes the Prime Minister should advocate against binge drinking rather than glorify it. Robert argued that such behavior sets a culture where drinking is about quantity and speed, not socializing. Opposition leader Bill Shorten humorously criticized Abbott for not adding lemonade to his beer, referencing a past incident where Abbott was labeled 'un-Australian' for ordering a light beer. Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott, stating there was nothing wrong with his actions and praising his fitness routine. Abbott's display of skolling a beer in six seconds was reminiscent of former Prime Minister Bob Hawke's similar behavior, but Robert noted that attitudes towards heavy drinking have shifted, and Abbott should have considered this change.

In Scott County, Indiana, there has been a significant rise in HIV cases, with 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary positive cases linked to intravenous drug use, primarily involving the painkiller Opana. This is a substantial increase from the county's usual five annual cases. The surge occurred more than two weeks into a 30-day needle exchange program approved by Governor Mike Pence. The program has distributed 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants, with 1,400 used syringes returned. Health officials anticipate the number of cases to rise as more people are tested. The outbreak has prompted discussions about extending the program and passing legislation to allow needle-exchange programs in other high-risk counties. However, Governor Pence, who opposes needle exchanges as an anti-drug policy, is reviewing reports and recommendations before deciding on the program's future. The Senate President Pro Tem, David Long, is uncertain about the long-term approach and the support for a bill that would allow needle-exchange programs in counties with high hepatitis C rates. The bill passed the House but faces a hearing in a house-senate conference committee. The federal government has banned public funding for needle exchange programs since 1989, adding to the financial challenges.

An Arsenal fan created a test for his girlfriend, Saskia, to quiz her on the club's details. The test, formatted like a school exam, included multiple-choice questions, tables to fill, and an "in your own words" section. Saskia scored 87%, which impressed her boyfriend enough to not end their relationship. Despite her high score, she struggled with some questions, such as naming all starting players and understanding player positions. Saskia's creative answers, like comparing Alexis Sanchez to Eden Hazard, earned her extra points. The test covered various topics, including the meaning of 'FC' in Arsenal FC, the nickname for Arsenal fans, the current manager, and the team's achievements. Saskia's performance was generally well-received by fellow football fans on social media, with many praising her knowledge and her boyfriend's creativity. However, some users felt the boyfriend had gone too far with his test.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellin Cartel, worked as a DEA undercover operative for 27 years after fleeing Colombia in the 1980s due to a life-threatening confrontation with his boss. Toro provided crucial information about his former associates, contributing significantly to the prosecution of key figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Despite his invaluable service, Toro was not granted U.S. citizenship as promised, leaving him technically living in the U.S. illegally after retiring due to health issues. The DEA declined to assist him, citing bureaucracy. Toro fears deportation, stating he would be killed within hours upon return to Colombia. His former colleague recently provided $5,000 for an operation, but Toro remains in limbo, unable to secure a green card, passport, or social security benefits. He is prepared to go into hiding if necessary, emphasizing his desire to fulfill the promised citizenship reward for his extensive service.

A 14-year-old girl from Kosi Kalan, Uttar Pradesh, India, allegedly gang-raped by five men, set herself on fire using kerosene on Tuesday. She is currently in critical condition with 70% burns at Delhi's Safdarjung Hospital. The incident occurred when she went outside her house to relieve herself. Her brother found her in flames and doused her with water. The accused men have been arrested. This case has heightened sensitivity around sexual assault in India, following the 2012 gang rape and murder of Jyoti Singh, a 23-year-old student in Delhi, which sparked nationwide protests and international outrage. The recent attacks have led to calls for increased protection for women and instances of vigilante justice. The documentary "India's Daughter," about Jyoti Singh's case, was banned due to concerns over potential further disorder.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal expressed his desire to defeat Manchester City in Sunday's derby at Old Trafford, despite Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw being ruled out due to fitness issues. Van Gaal stated that being fit for him means more than just being physically able, and both players are not yet at the required standard. The match presents an opportunity for United to potentially finish 2nd or 3rd in the table, avoiding a Champions League qualifying round. Van Gaal acknowledged City as a tough opponent but emphasized the importance of controlling aggression, learning from past mistakes, and not being overly motivated by revenge. He also praised the support of Manchester United fans and anticipates the unique atmosphere of the derby at Old Trafford.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans staged a protest during their Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium, leaving their seats empty for the first 10 minutes. The protest was against escalating ticket prices, sparked by the recent £5.14 billion TV rights deal. Tickets for the game started at £64, some of the highest in the Premier League. Fans displayed banners inside and outside the stadium, with one reading, "£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket." The protest was organized by Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement, Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly, and Spion Kop 1906 fan groups. They criticized the "extortionate" prices and the commodification of football, emphasizing the financial strain on fans. Roy Bentham of Spirit of Shankly called for tangible reductions in ticket prices to prevent losing a generation of fans. Further protests were anticipated after the match.

A newborn baby named Star Reader, diagnosed with biliary atresia in Barnsley, West Yorkshire, was saved after receiving a liver transplant from her mother's twin sister, Shanell Reader. Biliary atresia, affecting about 1 in 16,000 newborns, involves blocked or absent bile ducts, leading to jaundice and potential liver failure. Star's parents, Jade Reader and Matthew Bygrave, initially noticed her skin turning yellow, prompting medical tests. After an unsuccessful attempt to unblock her bile ducts, a liver transplant was deemed necessary. Neither parent was a suitable match, but Shanell Reader, Star's maternal aunt, was found to be an ideal candidate. Shanell agreed to donate part of her liver without hesitation, saving her niece's life. Star underwent the transplant in November and, after six weeks in the hospital, has since made a good recovery. She will require weekly blood tests, liver function tests, and lifelong anti-rejection medication. Both Star and Shanell are doing well, with Shanell expressing her gratitude for the opportunity to save her niece.

Chelsea football team's Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian participated in Audi's football challenge. In the first round, Hazard and Ake won against Remy and Willian with a score of 5-3. The second round involved playing over a £127,000 Audi R8 V10 Plus, where Hazard and Ake again emerged victorious, leading 6-0 after two rounds. The final challenge was to sink balls into convertible Audis from long range. Remy and Willian surprisingly won this round, with Willian accidentally smashing an Audi's wing mirror during his attempt. Despite the mishap, Remy's reaction and Willian's subsequent laughter suggest no serious repercussions.

Robert Dellinger, a 54-year-old former Fortune 500 executive from New Hampshire, was sentenced on Wednesday for a 2013 highway crash that killed a Vermont couple, Amanda Murphy and Jason Timmons, and their unborn baby. Dellinger, who had worked for companies like PPG Industries Inc., Sprint Corp., Delphi Corp., and General Electric Co., pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and one count of assault for the fetus' death. He faces 12 to 24 years in prison.

Dellinger claimed during his sentencing that he was not suicidal on the day of the crash, contradicting earlier statements to investigators that he was attempting to take his own life when he drove his pickup truck across a median at over 100 mph and collided with the couple's SUV. His wife, Deborah, testified that her husband is a man of ethics, integrity, and friendship, despite his serious health issues, including multiple sclerosis and medication withdrawal symptoms.
